I E_{\theta}\left[\left(X_{i, s}-p_{i, \theta}\left(X_{s-1}\right)\right)\left(X_{k, h}-p_{k, \theta}\left(X_{h-1}\right)\right)\right]=0
$$

to deduce that

$$
\begin{aligned}
I E_{\theta}\left[\left|\overline{Q^{N} M_{t}}\right|^{2}\right] & =N^{-2} \sum_{j=1}^{N} \sum_{k=1}^{N} c_{j}^{N} c_{k}^{N} I E_{\theta}\left[M_{j, t} M_{k, t}\right] \\
& =N^{-2} \sum_{j=1}^{N}\left(c_{j}^{N}\right)^{2} \sum_{s=1}^{t} I E_{\theta}\left[\left(X_{j, s}-p_{j, \theta}\left(X_{s-1}\right)\right)^{2}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence, it follows from Lemma E. 3 that

$$
\begin{aligned}
I E_{\theta}\left[\left|\overline{Q^{N} M_{t}}\right|^{2}\right] & =N^{-2} \sum_{j=1}^{N}\left(c_{j}^{N}\right)^{2} \sum_{s=1}^{t} I E_{\theta}\left[\left(X_{j, s}-p_{j, \theta}\left(X_{s-1}\right)\right)^{2}\right] \\
& =t N^{-2} \sum_{j=1}^{N}\left(c_{j}^{N}\right)^{2} m_{j}^{N}\left(1-m_{j}^{N}\right)+t N^{-2}\left\langle\left(c^{N}\right)^{2}, r_{\theta}^{N}\right\rangle \\
& =t N^{-1} w_{\infty}^{N}+t N^{-2}\left\langle\left(c^{N}\right)^{2}, r_{\theta}^{N}\right\rangle
\end{aligned}
$$

Finally, by applying Hölder inequality and then using that $\|v\|_{1} \leq N\|v\|_{\infty}$ for $v \in \mathbb{R}^{N}$, we obtain

$$
\left\langle\left(c^{N}\right)^{2}, r_{\theta}^{N}\right\rangle \leq\left\|\left(c^{N}\right)^{2}\right\|_{\infty}\left\|r_{\theta}^{N}\right\|_{1} \leq\left\|\left(c^{N}\right)^{2}\right\|_{\infty} N\left\|r_{\theta}^{N}\right\|_{\infty}
$$

and the result follows from inequality (84) and Lemma E.3.
For later use, let us mention the following immediate corollary of Lemmas E. 2 and E.5.
LEMMA E.6. There exists a constant $K>0$ depending only on $\lambda$ such that for all $t \geq 1$ and $N \geq 1$,

$$
I E_{\theta}\left[\left(\bar{U}_{t}\right)^{2}\right] \leq K t N^{-1}
$$

Proof. First, observe that $w_{\infty}^{N}$ defined in (31) satisfies $\left|w_{\infty}^{N}\right| \leq \lambda^{-2} / 4$ by Inequality (84), and then combine this fact with Lemmas E. 2 and E.5.

We are now in position to deal with the term $D_{T}^{N, 3}$ defined in (62).
Proposition E.7. There exists a constant $K>0$ depending only on $\lambda$ such that for all $N \geq 1, T \geq 2$ and $1 \leq \Delta \leq\lfloor T / 2\rfloor$,

$$
I E_{\theta}\left[D_{T}^{N, 3}\right] \leq K\left(\frac{1}{N}+\frac{(1-\lambda)^{\Delta}}{\Delta}+\frac{\Delta}{T}\right)
$$

Proof. First, observe that by stationarity,

$$
D_{T}^{N, 3}=\left\lvert\, \frac{2 N}{T}\lfloor T / 2 \Delta\rfloor I E_{\theta}\left[\left(\bar{U}_{2 \Delta}\right)^{2}\right]-\frac{N}{T}\lfloor T / \Delta\rfloor I E_{\theta}\left[\left(\bar{U}_{\Delta}\right)^{2}\right]-w_{\infty}^{N}\right\rvert\,
$$

Then, by using the triangle inequality, one can check that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left\lvert\, \frac{2 N}{T}\lfloor T / 2 \Delta\rfloor I E_{\theta}\left[\left(\bar{U}_{2 \Delta}\right)^{2}\right]-\frac{N}{T}\lfloor T / \Delta\rfloor I E_{\theta}\left[\left(\bar{U}_{\Delta}\right)^{2}\right]-w_{\infty}^{N}\right\rvert\,
\end{aligned}
$$

Then Lemmas E.2, E. 5 and E. 6 imply the result.
It remains to deal with $D_{\Delta, T}^{N, 2}$ and $D_{2 \Delta, T}^{N, 2}$. To that end, we shall use two additional lemmas. The first one is the following.

LEMMA E.8. There exists a constant $K>0$ depending only on $\lambda$ such that for all $N \geq 1$, $\Delta \geq 1$ and $t \geq 2$,

$$
\operatorname{Cov}_{\theta}\left[\left(\bar{U}_{\Delta}\right)^{2},\left(\bar{U}_{t \Delta}-\bar{U}_{(t-1) \Delta}\right)^{2}\right] \leq K N^{-2}(1-\lambda)^{(t-2) \Delta}
$$

Proof. First, use that $\bar{U}_{t}=N^{-1} \sum_{i=1}^{N} \sum_{s=1}^{t} Y_{i, s}$ to deduce that

$$
\operatorname{Cov}_{\theta}\left[\left(\bar{U}_{\Delta}\right)^{2},\left(\bar{U}_{t \Delta}-\bar{U}_{(t-1) \Delta}\right)^{2}\right]=N^{-4} \sum_{z_{1} \in F_{1}} \sum_{z_{2} \in F_{1}} \sum_{z_{3} \in F_{1}} \sum_{z_{4} \in F_{1}} \operatorname{Cov}_{\theta}\left[Y_{z_{1}} Y_{z_{2}}, Y_{z_{3}} Y_{z_{4}}\right]
$$

where $z_{k}=\left(i_{k}, t_{k}\right)$ for $k \in\{1, \ldots, 4\}$, and $F_{s}:=\{1, \ldots, N\} \times\{(s-1) \Delta+1, \ldots, s \Delta\}$ for $s \geq 1$. In the rest of the proof, we shall denote $\mathbf{z}=\left(z_{1}, z_{2}, z_{3}, z_{4}\right)$ and $B(\mathbf{z})=$ $\operatorname{Cov}_{\theta}\left[Y_{z_{1}} Y_{z_{2}}, Y_{z_{3}} Y_{z_{4}}\right]$. Notice that the covariance function $B(\mathbf{z})$ is symmetric with respect to $z_{1}$ and $z_{2}$, as well as with respect to $z_{3}$ and $z_{4}$. For each $p \in\{1, \ldots, 6\}$ and $s \geq 1$, we denote $\mathcal{C}_{p, s}$ the set of all vectors $\mathbf{z} \in F_{1} \times F_{1} \times F_{s} \times F_{s}$ satisfying the conditions of Item $p$ of Lemma 3.8 and such that $t_{1} \leq t_{2}$ and $t_{3} \leq t_{4}$. With this notation, one can check using the symmetry of the covariance function that the following inequality holds:

$$
\operatorname{Cov}_{\theta}\left[\left(\bar{U}_{\Delta}\right)^{2},\left(\bar{U}_{t \Delta}-\bar{U}_{(t-1) \Delta}\right)^{2}\right] \leq 4 N^{-4} \sum_{p=1}^{6} \sum_{\mathbf{z} \in \mathcal{C}_{p, t}}|B(\mathbf{z})|
$$

Notice that $\mathcal{C}_{1, t}=\mathcal{C}_{2, t}=\mathcal{C}_{5, t}=\emptyset$ for $t \geq 2$, so that we need only to control the sum of covariances for the cases $p \in\{3,4,6\}$. This is done in the 3 steps below.

Step 1. Here, we show that there exists a constant $K>0$ such that for all $N \geq 1, \Delta \geq 1$ and $t \geq 2$,

$$
\sum_{\mathbf{z} \in \mathcal{C}_{3, t}}|B(\mathbf{z})| \leq K N(1-\lambda)^{(t-2) \Delta+1}
$$

First, note that Item 3 of Lemma 3.8 implies that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\sum_{\mathbf{z} \in \mathcal{C}_{3, t}}|B(\mathbf{z})| & \leq K N^{2} \sum_{t_{1}=1}^{\Delta} \sum_{t_{3}=(t-1) \Delta+1}^{t \Delta}(1-\lambda)^{\left(t_{3}-t_{1}\right)} N^{-1} \\
& =K N(1-\lambda)^{(t-2) \Delta+1} \sum_{k=0}^{\Delta-1}(1-\lambda)^{k} \sum_{t_{1}=1}^{\Delta}(1-\lambda)^{\Delta-t_{1}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Step 1 follows by noticing that $\sum_{t_{1}=1}^{\Delta}(1-\lambda)^{\Delta-t_{1}}=\sum_{k=0}^{\Delta-1}(1-\lambda)^{k}$, and then by using that $\sum_{k=0}^{\Delta-1}(1-\lambda)^{k} \leq \sum_{k=0}^{\infty}(1-\lambda)^{k} \leq \lambda^{-1}$.

Step 2. Here, we prove that there exists a constant $K>0$ such that for all $N \geq 1, \Delta \geq 1$ and $t \geq 2$,

$$
\sum_{\mathbf{z} \in \mathcal{C}_{4, t}}|B(\mathbf{z})| \leq K N(1-\lambda)^{(t-2) \Delta+1}
$$

First, by Remark 3.9, we can write

$$
\sum_{\mathbf{z} \in \mathcal{C}_{4, t}}|B(\mathbf{z})|=\sum_{\mathbf{z} \in \mathcal{C}_{4, t}} \mathbf{1}_{\left\{z_{1}=z_{2}, z_{3} \neq z_{4}\right\}}|B(\mathbf{z})|+\sum_{\mathbf{z} \in \mathcal{C}_{4, t}} \mathbf{1}_{\left\{z_{1} \neq z_{2}, z_{3}=z_{4}\right\}}|B(\mathbf{z})|
$$

To conclude, we apply Item 4 of Lemma 3.8 to obtain an upper bound for each one of the terms on the right hand side of the above identity. Since both terms are treated very similarly, we explain how we handle the first term only. By applying Item 4 of Lemma 3.8 to the first one, we obtain that

$$
\sum_{\mathbf{z} \in \mathcal{C}_{4, t}} \mathbf{1}_{\left\{z_{1}=z_{2}, z_{3} \neq z_{4}\right\}}|B(\mathbf{z})| \leq K N^{3} \sum_{t_{1}=1}^{\Delta} \sum_{t_{3}=(t-1) \Delta+1}^{t \Delta} \sum_{t_{4}=t_{3}}^{t \Delta}(1-\lambda)^{\left(t_{4}-t_{3}\right)+\left(t_{3}-t_{1}\right)} N^{-2}
$$

Now, since for any $(t-1) \Delta+1 \leq t_{3} \leq t \Delta$,

$$
\sum_{t_{4}=t_{3}}^{t \Delta}(1-\lambda)^{\left(t_{4}-t_{3}\right)}=\sum_{k=0}^{t \Delta-t_{3}}(1-\lambda)^{k} \leq \sum_{k=0}^{\Delta-1}(1-\lambda)^{k} \leq \lambda^{-1}
$$

we can then proceed as in Step 1 to conclude that

$$
\sum_{\mathbf{z} \in \mathcal{C}_{4, t}} \mathbf{1}_{\left\{z_{1}=z_{2}, z_{3} \neq z_{4}\right\}}|B(\mathbf{z})| \leq K N(1-\lambda)^{(t-2) \Delta+1}
$$

Step 3. Here, we prove that there exists a constant $K>0$ such that for all $N \geq 1, \Delta \geq 1$ and $t \geq 2$,

$$
\sum_{\mathbf{z} \in \mathcal{C}_{6, t}}|B(\mathbf{z})| \leq K N^{2}(1-\lambda)^{(t-2) \Delta+1}
$$

By applying Item 6 of Lemma 3.8 and inequality (67), one can check that

$$
\sum_{\mathbf{z} \in \mathcal{C}_{6, t}}|B(\mathbf{z})| \leq K N^{4} \sum_{t_{1}=1}^{\Delta} \sum_{t_{2}=t_{1}}^{\Delta} \sum_{t_{3}=(t-1) \Delta+1}^{t \Delta} N^{-2}(1-\lambda)^{t_{3}-t_{1}}
$$

Some algebraic computations imply that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\sum_{t_{1}=1}^{\Delta} \sum_{t_{2}=t_{1}}^{\Delta} \sum_{t_{3}=(t-1) \Delta+1}^{t \Delta}(1-\lambda)^{t_{3}-t_{1}} \leq(1-\lambda)^{(t-2) \Delta+1}\left(\sum_{k=0}^{\Delta-1}(1-\lambda)^{k}\right) & \\
& \times\left(\sum_{k=0}^{\Delta-1}(k+1)(1-\lambda)^{k}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Putting together these estimates and using the fact that $\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}(k+1)(1-\lambda)^{k}<\infty$, we conclude the proof of Step 3.

Finally, combining Steps 1 through 3 and (66), the result follows.

LEMMA E.9. There exists a constant $K$ depending only on $\lambda, \mu$ and $p$, such that for all $N \geq 1$ and $\Delta \geq 1$,

$$
\operatorname{Var}_{\theta}\left[\left(\bar{U}_{\Delta}\right)^{2}\right] \leq K \Delta^{2} N^{-2}
$$

Proof. We use the notation of the proof of Lemma E.8, except that we now denote $\mathcal{C}_{1,6}$ the set of all vectors $\mathbf{z} \in \mathbf{F}_{\mathbf{1}} \times \mathbf{F}_{\mathbf{1}} \times \mathbf{F}_{\mathbf{1}} \times \mathbf{F}_{\mathbf{1}}$ satisfying the conditions of Item 7, of Lemma 3.8, that is, without imposing the constraint that $t_{1}>t_{4}$ or $t_{3}>t_{2}$. By taking $t=1$ in inequality (66), it follows that

$$
\operatorname{Var}_{\theta}\left[\left(\bar{U}_{\Delta}\right)^{2}\right] \leq 4 N^{-4}\left(\sum_{p=1}^{6} \sum_{\mathbf{z} \in \mathcal{C}_{1, p}}|B(\mathbf{z})|\right)
$$

So we need to show that the sum of covariances is at most $K \Delta^{2} N^{2}$. This is done in the 5 steps below.

Step 1. First, we show that there exists a constant $K>0$ such that for all $N \geq 1$ and $\Delta \geq 1$,

$$
\sum_{p=1}^{2} \sum_{\mathbf{z} \in \mathcal{C}_{1, p}}|B(\mathbf{z})| \leq K(\Delta N)^{2}
$$

By Item 1 and Item 2 of Lemma 3.8, we have that

$$
\sum_{p=1}^{2} \sum_{\mathbf{z} \in \mathcal{C}_{1, p}}|B(\mathbf{z})| \leq\left|\mathcal{C}_{1,1}\right|+\left|\mathcal{C}_{1,2}\right| \leq \Delta N+2 \Delta N(\Delta N-1) \leq 3(\Delta N)^{2}
$$

so that the result follows with $K=3$.
Step 2. Next, we show that there exists a constant $K>0$ such that for all $N \geq 1$ and $\Delta \geq 1$,

$$
\sum_{\mathbf{z} \in \mathcal{C}_{1,3}}|B(\mathbf{z})| \leq K N \Delta^{2}
$$

Item 3 of Lemma 3.8, ensures that

$$
\sum_{\mathbf{z} \in \mathcal{C}_{1,3}}|B(\mathbf{z})| \leq K N^{2} \sum_{t_{1}=1}^{\Delta} \sum_{t_{3}=1}^{\Delta}(1-\lambda)^{\left|t_{3}-t_{1}\right|} N^{-1}
$$

Since $\sum_{t_{1}=1}^{\Delta} \sum_{t_{3}=1}^{\Delta}(1-\lambda)^{\left|t_{3}-t_{1}\right|} \leq \Delta^{2}$, the result follows from the previous inequality.
Step 3. Here, we show that there exists a constant $K>0$ such that for all $N \geq 1$ and $\Delta \geq 1$,

$$
\sum_{\mathbf{z} \in \mathcal{C}_{1,4}}|B(\mathbf{z})| \leq K N \Delta^{2}
$$

We proceed very similarly as in the proof of Step 2 of Lemma E.8. First, observe that we can write (see Remark 3.9),

$$
\sum_{\mathbf{z} \in \mathcal{C}_{1,4}}|B(\mathbf{z})|=\sum_{\mathbf{z} \in \mathcal{C}_{1,4}} \mathbf{1}_{\left\{z_{1}=z_{2}, z_{3} \neq z_{4}\right\}}|B(\mathbf{z})|+\sum_{\mathbf{z} \in \mathcal{C}_{1,4}} \mathbf{1}_{\left\{z_{1} \neq z_{2}, z_{3}=z_{4}\right\}}|B(\mathbf{z})|
$$

To obtain the result, we apply Item 4 of Lemma 3.8 to obtain an upper bound for each term on the right hand side of the above identity. Since both terms are treated very similarly, we explain how we deal with the first term only. By applying Point 4 of Lemma 3.8 to the first one, we obtain that

$$
\sum_{\mathbf{z} \in \mathcal{C}_{1,4}} \mathbf{1}_{\left\{z_{1}=z_{2}, z_{3} \neq z_{4}\right\}}|B(\mathbf{z})| \leq K N^{3} \sum_{t_{1}=1}^{\Delta} \sum_{t_{3}=1}^{\Delta} \sum_{t_{4}=1}^{\Delta} \mathbf{1}_{\left\{t_{3} \leq t_{4}\right\}}(1-\lambda)^{\left|s_{3}-s_{2}\right|+\left|s_{2}-s_{1}\right|} N^{-2}
$$

where $s_{1} \leq s_{2} \leq s_{3}$ denotes the ordering of the triple $\left(t_{1}, t_{3}, t_{4}\right)$. Next, we use that $\left|s_{3}-s_{2}\right|+$ $\left|s_{2}-s_{1}\right| \geq t_{4}-t_{3}$ to deduce that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\sum_{t_{1}=1}^{\Delta} \sum_{t_{2}=1}^{\Delta} \sum_{t_{4}=1}^{\Delta} \mathbf{1}_{\left\{t_{3} \leq t_{4}\right\}}(1-\lambda)^{\left|s_{3}-s_{2}\right|+\left|s_{2}-s_{1}\right|} & \leq \Delta \sum_{t_{3}=1}^{\Delta} \sum_{t_{4}=1}^{\Delta} \mathbf{1}_{\left\{t_{3} \leq t_{4}\right\}}(1-\lambda)^{t_{4}-t_{3}} \\
& \leq \Delta^{2} \sum_{k=0}^{\Delta-1}(1-\lambda)^{k} \leq \lambda^{-1} \Delta^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

As a consequence, we obtain that

$$
\sum_{\mathbf{z} \in \mathcal{C}_{1,4}} \mathbf{1}_{\left\{z_{1}=z_{2}, z_{3} \neq z_{4}\right\}}|B(\mathbf{z})| \leq K N \lambda^{-1} \Delta^{2}
$$

and the result follows.
Step 4. In this step, we show that there exists a constant $K>0$ such that for all $N \geq 1$ and $\Delta \geq 1$,

$$
\sum_{\mathbf{z} \in \mathcal{C}_{1,5}}|B(\mathbf{z})| \leq K N^{2} \Delta^{2}
$$

We start observing that

$$
\sum_{\mathbf{z} \in \mathcal{C}_{1,5}}|B(\mathbf{z})|=\sum_{\mathbf{z} \in \mathcal{C}_{1,5}} \mathbf{1}_{\left\{z_{1}=z_{3}, z_{2} \neq z_{4}\right\}}|B(\mathbf{z})|+\sum_{\mathbf{z} \in \mathcal{C}_{1,5}} \mathbf{1}_{\left\{z_{1} \neq z_{3}, z_{2}=z_{4}\right\}}|B(\mathbf{z})|
$$

Hence, it suffices to provide an upper bound for each term on the right hand side of the above inequality. We will explain how we deal with the first one only. The second one can be treated similarly. By Item 5 of Lemma 3.8, we have that

$$
\sum_{\mathbf{z} \in \mathcal{C}_{1,5}} \mathbf{1}_{\left\{z_{1}=z_{3}, z_{2} \neq z_{4}\right\}}|B(\mathbf{z})| \leq K N^{3} \sum_{t_{1}=1}^{\Delta} \sum_{t_{2}=1}^{\Delta} \sum_{t_{4}=1}^{\Delta} \mathbf{1}_{\left\{t_{2} \leq t_{4}\right\}}(1-\lambda)^{\left(t_{4}-t_{2}\right)} N^{-1}
$$

Hence, by observing that

$$
\sum_{t_{1}=1}^{\Delta} \sum_{t_{2}=1}^{\Delta} \sum_{t_{4}=1}^{\Delta} \mathbf{1}_{\left\{t_{2} \leq t_{4}\right\}}(1-\lambda)^{\left(t_{4}-t_{2}\right)} \leq \Delta^{2} \sum_{k=0}^{\Delta-1}(1-\lambda)^{k} \leq \Delta^{2} \lambda^{-1}
$$

the result follows.
Step 5. Finally, we show that there exists a constant $K>0$ such that for all $N \geq 1$ and $\Delta \geq 1$,

$$
\sum_{\mathbf{z} \in \mathcal{C}_{1,6}}|B(\mathbf{z})| \leq K N^{2} \Delta^{2}
$$

We start from

$$
\begin{aligned}
\sum_{\mathbf{z} \in \mathcal{C}_{1,6}}|B(\mathbf{z})| \leq \sum_{\mathbf{z} \in \mathcal{C}_{1,6}}\left[\mathbf{1}_{\left\{t_{3} \leq t_{4} \leq t_{1} \leq t_{2}\right\}}+\mathbf{1}_{\left\{t_{1} \leq t_{2} \leq t_{3} \leq t_{4}\right\}}\right]|B(\mathbf{z})|+\sum_{\mathbf{z} \in \mathcal{C}_{1,6}}\left[\mathbf{1}_{\left\{t_{1} \leq t_{3} \leq t_{2} \leq t_{4}\right\}}\right. \\
\left.\quad+\mathbf{1}_{\left\{t_{3} \leq t_{1} \leq t_{4} \leq t_{2}\right\}}+\mathbf{1}_{\left\{t_{1} \leq t_{3} \leq t_{4} \leq t_{2}\right\}}+\mathbf{1}_{\left\{t_{3} \leq t_{1} \leq t_{2} \leq t_{4}\right\}}\right]|B(\mathbf{z})|
\end{aligned}
$$

In the sequel, we handle the two terms on the right-hand side of the above inequality separately.

Step 5.1 Here, we show that there exists a constant $K>0$ such that for all $N \geq 1$ and $\Delta \geq 1$,

$$
\sum_{\mathbf{z} \in \mathcal{C}_{1,6}}\left[\mathbf{1}_{\left\{t_{3} \leq t_{4} \leq t_{1} \leq t_{2}\right\}}+\mathbf{1}_{\left\{t_{1} \leq t_{2} \leq t_{3} \leq t_{4}\right\}}\right]|B(\mathbf{z})| \leq K N^{2} \Delta
$$

By Item 6 of Lemma 3.8,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \sum_{\mathbf{z} \in \mathcal{C}_{1,6}} \mathbf{1}_{\left\{t_{3} \leq t_{4} \leq t_{1} \leq t_{2}\right\}}|B(\mathbf{z})| \leq K N^{4} \sum_{t_{1}=1}^{\Delta} \sum_{t_{2}=1}^{\Delta} \sum_{t_{3}=1}^{\Delta} \sum_{t_{4}=1}^{\Delta} \mathbf{1}_{\left\{t_{3} \leq t_{4} \leq t_{1} \leq t_{2}\right\}} \times \\
& (1-\lambda)^{t_{2}-t_{3}} N^{-2}
\end{aligned}
$$

We upper bound

$$
\sum_{t_{1}=1}^{\Delta} \sum_{t_{2}=1}^{\Delta} \sum_{t_{3}=1}^{\Delta} \sum_{t_{4}=1}^{\Delta} \mathbf{1}_{\left\{t_{3} \leq t_{4} \leq t_{1} \leq t_{2}\right\}}(1-\lambda)^{t_{2}-t_{3}} \leq \Delta\left(\sum_{k=0}^{\Delta-1}(1-\lambda)^{k}\right)^{3}
$$

such that

$$
\sum_{\mathbf{z} \in \mathcal{C}_{1,6}} \mathbf{1}_{\left\{t_{3} \leq t_{4} \leq t_{1} \leq t_{2}\right\}}|B(\mathbf{z})| \leq K N^{2} \Delta
$$

Proceeding similarly, we can also check that $\sum_{\mathbf{z} \in \mathcal{C}_{1,6}} \mathbf{1}_{\left\{t_{3} \leq t_{4} \leq t_{1} \leq t_{2}\right\}}|B(\mathbf{z})| \leq K N^{2} \Delta$. This concludes the proof of Step 5.1

Step 5.2 Here we show that there exists a constant $K>0$ such that for all $N \geq 1$ and $\Delta \geq 1$,
$\sum_{\mathbf{z} \in \mathcal{C}_{1,6}}\left[\mathbf{1}_{\left\{t_{1} \leq t_{3} \leq t_{2} \leq t_{4}\right\}}+\mathbf{1}_{\left\{t_{3} \leq t_{1} \leq t_{4} \leq t_{2}\right\}}+\mathbf{1}_{\left\{t_{1} \leq t_{3} \leq t_{4} \leq t_{2}\right\}}+\mathbf{1}_{\left\{t_{3} \leq t_{1} \leq t_{2} \leq t_{4}\right\}}\right]|B(\mathbf{z})| \leq K N^{2} \Delta^{2}$.
From Item 7 of Lemma 3.8, we deduce that

$$
\sum_{\mathbf{z} \in \mathcal{C}_{1,6}} \mathbf{1}_{\left\{t_{1} \leq t_{3} \leq t_{2} \leq t_{4}\right\}}|B(\mathbf{z})| \leq K \sum_{\mathbf{z} \in \mathcal{C}_{1,6}} \mathbf{1}_{\left\{t_{1} \leq t_{3} \leq t_{2} \leq t_{4}\right\}}(1-\lambda)^{\left(t_{4}-t_{2}\right)+\left(t_{3}-t_{1}\right)} N^{-2}
$$

Since

$$
\sum_{t_{1}=1}^{\Delta} \sum_{t_{2}=1}^{\Delta} \sum_{t_{3}=1}^{\Delta} \sum_{t_{4}=1}^{\Delta} \mathbf{1}_{\left\{t_{1} \leq t_{3} \leq t_{2} \leq t_{4}\right\}}(1-\lambda)^{\left(t_{4}-t_{2}\right)+\left(t_{3}-t_{1}\right)} \leq \Delta^{2}\left(\sum_{k=0}^{\Delta-1}(1-\lambda)^{k}\right)^{2}
$$

it then follows that

$$
\sum_{\mathbf{z} \in \mathcal{C}_{1,6}} \mathbf{1}_{\left\{t_{1} \leq t_{3} \leq t_{2} \leq t_{4}\right\}}(1-\lambda)^{\left(t_{1}-t_{3}\right)+\left(t_{2}-t_{4}\right)} N^{-2} \leq N^{2} \Delta^{2} \lambda^{-2}
$$

such that

$$
\sum_{\mathbf{z} \in \mathcal{C}_{1,6}} \mathbf{1}_{\left\{t_{1} \leq t_{3} \leq t_{2} \leq t_{4}\right\}}|B(\mathbf{z})| \leq K N^{2} \Delta^{2}
$$

Proceeding similarly, we can also check the three other cases, concluding the proof of Step 5.2 .

Combining Steps 5.1, 5.2 and 5.3, we obtain

$$
\sum_{\mathbf{z} \in \mathcal{C}_{1,6}}|B(\mathbf{z})| \leq K N^{2} \Delta^{2}
$$

concluding the proof of Step 5.
By summing all the upper bounds provided by the Steps 1 through 5, we conclude the proof of Lemma E.9.

We are now in position to handle the terms $D_{\Delta, T}^{N, 2}$ and $D_{2 \Delta, T}^{N, 2}$.
Proposition E.10. There exists a constant $K$ depending only on $\lambda$ such that for all $N \geq 1, T \geq 2$ and $1 \leq \Delta \leq\lfloor T / 2\rfloor$, we have that

$$
I E_{\theta}\left[\left(D_{\Delta, T}^{N, 2}\right)^{2}+\left(D_{2 \Delta, T}^{N, 2}\right)^{2}\right] \leq K \frac{\Delta}{T}
$$

Proof. Clearly, the result will follow if we can show that $I E_{\theta}\left[\left(D_{\Delta, T}^{N, 2}\right)^{2}\right] \leq K \Delta T^{-1}$. To establish this inequality, first observe that

$$
\begin{aligned}
I E_{\theta}\left[\left(D_{\Delta, T}^{N, 2}\right)^{2}\right] & =\frac{N^{2}}{T^{2}} \operatorname{Var}_{\theta}\left[\sum_{t=1}^{\lfloor T / \Delta\rfloor}\left(\bar{U}_{t \Delta}-\bar{U}_{(t-1) \Delta}\right)^{2}\right] \\
& =\frac{N^{2}}{T^{2}} \sum_{t=1}^{\lfloor T / \Delta\rfloor} \sum_{s=1}^{\lfloor T / \Delta\rfloor} \operatorname{Cov}_{\theta}\left[\left(\bar{U}_{t \Delta}-\bar{U}_{(t-1) \Delta}\right)^{2},\left(\bar{U}_{s \Delta}-\bar{U}_{(s-1) \Delta}\right)^{2}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

Next, we use the stationarity of the system to conclude that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& I E_{\theta}\left[\left(D_{\Delta, T}^{N, 2}\right)^{2}\right]=\frac{N^{2}}{T^{2}}\lfloor T / \Delta\rfloor \operatorname{Var}_{\theta}\left[\left(\bar{U}_{\Delta}\right)^{2}\right] \\
& \quad+2 \frac{N^{2}}{T^{2}} \sum_{t=2}^{\lfloor T / \Delta\rfloor}(\lfloor T / \Delta\rfloor-t+1) \operatorname{Cov}_{\theta}\left[\left(\bar{U}_{\Delta}\right)^{2},\left(\bar{U}_{t \Delta}-\bar{U}_{(t-1) \Delta}\right)^{2}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

As a consequence of Lemma E. 8 and of the fact that $\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}(1-\lambda)^{k \Delta}<\infty$, it then follows that

$$
I E_{\theta}\left[\left(D_{\Delta, T}^{N, 2}\right)^{2}\right] \leq \frac{N^{2}}{T \Delta} \operatorname{Var}_{\theta}\left[\left(\bar{U}_{\Delta}\right)^{2}\right]+K(\Delta T)^{-1}
$$

Hence, using Lemma E.9, we establish the desired inequality and conclude the proof.

E.3. Proof of Equation (33). The proof relies on a decomposition of the error $\left|\hat{v}-v_{\infty}^{N}\right|$ (see Inequality (69)). Each term of the decomposition is then controlled by one of the four Propositions E.11-E.14. Their proofs are quite similar and less involved than the proofs given in the previous subsection.

Recall that

$$
\hat{v}=\frac{1}{T^{2}} \sum_{i=1}^{N}\left(Z_{i, T}-\bar{Z}_{T}\right)^{2}-\frac{N}{T^{2}} \bar{Z}_{T}+\frac{1}{T^{3}} \sum_{i=1}^{N}\left(Z_{i, T}\right)^{2}
$$

and that $\hat{m}=\bar{Z}_{T} / T$. Therefore,

$$
\left|\hat{v}-v_{\infty}^{N}\right| \leq \Upsilon_{T}^{N, 1}+\Upsilon_{T}^{N, 2}+\Upsilon_{T}^{N, 3}
$$

where

$$
\begin{gathered}
\Upsilon_{T}^{N, 1}=\left|\sum_{i=1}^{N}\left[\left(\frac{Z_{i, T}}{T}-\frac{\bar{Z}_{T}}{T}\right)^{2}-\left(m_{i}^{N}-\overline{m^{N}}\right)^{2}\right]-\frac{N}{T} \overline{m^{N}}+\frac{1}{T} \sum_{i=1}^{N}\left(m_{i}^{N}\right)^{2}\right| \\
\Upsilon_{T}^{N, 2}=\frac{N}{T}\left|\hat{m}-\overline{m^{N}}\right|, \text { and } \Upsilon_{T}^{N, 3}=\frac{1}{T}\left|\sum_{i=1}^{N}\left(\frac{Z_{i, T}}{T}\right)^{2}-\left(m_{i}^{N}\right)^{2}\right|
\end{gathered}
$$

Proposition E.11. There exists a constant $K$ depending only on $\lambda$ such that for all $N \geq 1$ and $T \geq 1$,

$$
I E_{\theta}\left[\Upsilon_{T}^{N, 2}+\Upsilon_{T}^{N, 3}\right] \leq K\left(\frac{N}{T^{2}}+\frac{N^{1 / 2}}{T^{3 / 2}}\left(1+\sqrt{v_{\infty}^{N}}\right)\right)
$$

Proof. First, remind that $I E_{\theta}\left[Z_{i, T} / T\right]=m_{i}^{N}$ and so $I E_{\theta}[\hat{m}]=\overline{m^{N}}$. On the one hand, by Cauchy-Schwarz, $I E_{\theta}\left[\Upsilon_{T}^{N, 2}\right] \leq N T^{-1}\left(\operatorname{Var}_{\theta}(\hat{m})\right)^{1 / 2} \leq K N^{1 / 2} T^{-3 / 2}$ by Equation (32). On the other hand, by first rewriting $\Upsilon_{T}^{N, 3}$ as (recall that $U_{i, T}=Z_{i, T}-T m_{i}^{N}$ ),

$$
\Upsilon_{T}^{N, 3}=\frac{1}{T}\left|\sum_{i=1}^{N}\left(\frac{U_{i, T}}{T}\right)^{2}+2 \sum_{i=1}^{N}\left(m_{i}^{N}-\overline{m^{N}}\right) \frac{U_{i, T}}{T}+2 \frac{N}{T} \overline{m^{N}} \bar{U}_{T}\right|
$$

and then using the triangle inequality, we obtain that

$$
I E_{\theta}\left[\Upsilon_{T}^{N, 3}\right] \leq \frac{1}{T^{3}} \sum_{i=1}^{N} I E_{\theta}\left[\left(U_{i, T}\right)^{2}\right]+\frac{2}{T^{2}} \sum_{i=1}^{N}\left|m_{i}^{N}-\overline{m^{N}}\right| I E_{\theta}\left[\left|U_{i, T}\right|\right]+2 \frac{N}{T^{2}} \overline{m^{N}} I E_{\theta}\left[\left|\bar{U}_{T}\right|\right]
$$

Now, by stationarity and Lemma 3.7,

$$
\begin{gathered}
\operatorname{Var}_{\theta}\left(Z_{i, T}\right)=T \operatorname{Var}_{\theta}\left(X_{i, 0}\right)+2 \sum_{t=1}^{T}(T-t) \operatorname{Cov}_{\theta}\left(X_{i, 0}, X_{i, t}\right) \\
\leq T \operatorname{Var}_{\theta}\left(X_{i, 0}\right)+K T / N \leq K T
\end{gathered}
$$

so that

$$
\frac{1}{T^{3}} \sum_{i=1}^{N} I E_{\theta}\left[\left(U_{i, T}\right)^{2}\right]=\frac{1}{T^{3}} \sum_{i=1}^{N} \operatorname{Var}_{\theta}\left(Z_{i, T}\right) \leq K N T^{-2}
$$

Moreover, by using Cauchy-Schwarz inequality and then Jensen inequality, we deduce that

$$
\sum_{i=1}^{N}\left|m_{i}^{N}-\overline{m^{N}}\right| \mathbb{E}_{\theta}\left[\left|U_{i, T}\right|\right] \leq \sqrt{\sum_{i=1}^{N}\left|m_{i}^{N}-\overline{m^{N}}\right|^{2}} \sqrt{\sum_{i=1}^{N} \mathbb{E}_{\theta}\left[\left(U_{i, T}\right)^{2}\right]}
$$

Hence, using once more Inequality (70) and reminding that $v_{\infty}^{N}=\sum_{i=1}^{N}\left|m_{i}^{N}-\overline{m^{N}}\right|^{2}$, we obtain that

$$
\frac{2}{T^{2}} \sum_{i=1}^{N}\left|m_{i}^{N}-\overline{m^{N}}\right| \mathbb{E}_{\theta}\left[\left|U_{i, T}\right|\right] \leq K \frac{N^{1 / 2}}{T^{3 / 2}} \sqrt{v_{\infty}^{N}}
$$

Finally, by combining Jensen inequality and Lemma E.6, it follows that $\mathbb{E}_{\theta}\left[\left|\bar{U}_{T}\right|\right] \leq$ $\sqrt{\mathbb{E}_{\theta}\left[\left|\bar{U}_{T}\right|^{2}\right]} \leq K T^{1 / 2} N^{-1 / 2}$ so that

$$
2 \frac{N}{T^{2}} \overline{m^{N}} \mathbb{E}_{\theta}\left[\left|\bar{U}_{T}\right|\right] \leq K N^{1 / 2} T^{-3 / 2}
$$

where we have also used that that $\left|\overline{m^{N}}\right| \leq 1$. Putting together the above estimates, it then follows that

$$
\mathbb{E}_{\theta}\left[\Upsilon_{T}^{N, 3}\right] \leq K\left(\frac{N}{T^{2}}+\frac{N^{1 / 2}}{T^{3 / 2}} \sqrt{v_{\infty}^{N}}\right)
$$

and the result follows since we have already proved that $\mathbb{E}_{\theta}\left[\Upsilon_{T}^{N, 2}\right] \leq K N^{1 / 2} T^{-3 / 2}$.
We now turn to the study of $\Upsilon_{T}^{N, 1}$. Using that

$$
(a-b)^{2}-(\bar{a}-\bar{b})^{2}=(a-b)^{2}-(a-\bar{b})^{2}+(a-\bar{a})^{2}+2(a-\bar{a})(\bar{a}-\bar{b})
$$

we obtain that $\Upsilon_{T}^{N, 1} \leq \Upsilon_{T}^{N, 1,1}+\Upsilon_{T}^{N, 1,2}+\Upsilon_{T}^{N, 1,3}$, where

$$
\begin{gathered}
\Upsilon_{T}^{N, 1,1}=\left|\sum_{i=1}^{N}\left(\frac{Z_{i, T}}{T}-\frac{\bar{Z}_{T}}{T}\right)^{2}-\left(\frac{Z_{i, T}}{T}-\overline{m^{N}}\right)^{2}\right| \\
\Upsilon_{T}^{N, 1,2}=\left|\sum_{i=1}^{N}\left(\frac{Z_{i, T}}{T}-m_{i}^{N}\right)^{2}-\frac{N}{T} \overline{m^{N}}+\frac{1}{T} \sum_{i=1}^{N}\left(m_{i}^{N}\right)^{2}\right|
\end{gathered}
$$

and

$$
\Upsilon_{T}^{N, 1,3}=2\left|\sum_{i=1}^{N}\left(\frac{Z_{i, T}}{T}-m_{i}^{N}\right)\left(m_{i}^{N}-\overline{m^{N}}\right)\right|
$$

Furthermore, remind that $U_{i, t}=Z_{i, t}-t m_{i}^{N}$ and so we write $\Upsilon_{T}^{N, 1,2}=\Upsilon_{T}^{N, 1,2,1}+\Upsilon_{T}^{N, 1,2,2}$, with

$$
\Upsilon_{T}^{N, 1,2,1}=\left|\sum_{i=1}^{N}\left(\frac{U_{i, T}}{T}\right)^{2}-\mathbb{E}_{\theta}\left(\left(\frac{U_{i, T}}{T}\right)^{2}\right)\right|
$$

and

$$
\Upsilon_{T}^{N, 1,2,2}=\left|\sum_{i=1}^{N} \mathbb{E}_{\theta}\left(\left(\frac{U_{i, T}}{T}\right)^{2}\right)-\frac{N}{T} \overline{m^{N}}+\frac{1}{T} \sum_{i=1}^{N}\left(m_{i}^{N}\right)^{2}\right|
$$

Proposition E.12. For all $N \geq 1$ and $T \geq 1$, there exists a constant $K$ depending only on $\lambda$ such that

$$
I E_{\theta}\left[\Upsilon_{T}^{N, 1,1}+\Upsilon_{T}^{N, 1,2,2}\right] \leq K \frac{1}{T}
$$

Proof. Adapting the argument used in the beginning of Proposition E.1, we have

$$
\Upsilon_{T}^{N, 1,1}=N\left(\frac{Z_{T}}{T}-\overline{m^{N}}\right)^{2}
$$

Hence, Equation (32) implies that $I E_{\theta} \Upsilon_{T}^{N, 1,1} \leq K / T$.
Second, remark that $\Upsilon_{T}^{N, 1,2,2}$ is not random and rewrites as

$$
\Upsilon_{T}^{N, 1,2,2}=\left|\sum_{i=1}^{N} \operatorname{Var}_{\theta}\left(\frac{Z_{i, T}}{T}\right)-\frac{N}{T} \overline{m^{N}}+\frac{1}{T} \sum_{i=1}^{N}\left(m_{i}^{N}\right)^{2}\right|
$$

Using Equation (70) and the fact that $\operatorname{Var}_{\theta}\left(X_{i, 0}\right)=m_{i}^{N}-\left(m_{i}^{N}\right)^{2}$ we conclude that $I E_{\theta} \Upsilon_{T}^{N, 1,2,2} \leq K / T$

Proposition E.13. For all $N \geq 1$ and $T \geq 1$, there exists a constant $K$ depending only on $\lambda$ such that

$$
I E_{\theta}\left|\Upsilon_{T}^{N, 1,3}\right|^{2} \leq \frac{K}{T} \sum_{i=1}^{N}\left|m_{i}^{N}-\overline{m^{N}}\right|^{2}
$$

Proof. Clearly,

$$
I E_{\theta}\left|\Upsilon_{T}^{N, 1,3}\right|^{2} \leq \frac{4}{T^{2}} \sum_{i, j=1}^{N}\left|\operatorname{Cov}_{\theta}\left(U_{i, T}, U_{j, T}\right)\right|\left|m_{i}^{N}-\overline{m^{N}}\right|\left|m_{j}^{N}-\overline{m^{N}}\right|
$$

But, by stationarity and using Lemma 3.7,

$$
\left|\operatorname{Cov}_{\theta}\left(U_{i, T}, U_{j, T}\right)\right| \leq \sum_{s, t=1}^{T}\left|\operatorname{Cov}_{\theta}\left(X_{i, s}, X_{j, t}\right)\right| \leq T\left|\operatorname{Cov}_{\theta}\left(X_{i, 0}, X_{j, 0}\right)\right|+K T / N
$$

Moreover,

$$
\left|\operatorname{Cov}_{\theta}\left(X_{i, 0}, X_{j, 0}\right)\right| \leq\left(m_{i}^{N}-\left(m_{i}^{N}\right)^{2}\right) \mathbf{1}_{\{i=j\}}+K / N \mathbf{1}_{\{i \neq j\}}
$$

such that all in all

$$
\begin{aligned}
& I E_{\theta}\left|\Upsilon_{T}^{N, 1,3}\right|^{2} \\
& \leq \frac{K}{T}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{N}\left[\frac{1}{N}+\left(m_{i}^{N}-\left(m_{i}^{N}\right)^{2}\right)\right]\left(m_{i}^{N}-\overline{m^{N}}\right)^{2}+\frac{1}{N} \sum_{i \neq j}\left|m_{i}^{N}-\overline{m^{N}}\right|\left|m_{j}^{N}-\overline{m^{N}}\right|\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Since $m_{i}^{N}-\left(m_{i}^{N}\right)^{2} \leq 1$ and $\left|m_{i}^{N}-\overline{m^{N}}\right|\left|m_{j}^{N}-\overline{m^{N}}\right| \leq\left(m_{i}^{N}-\overline{m^{N}}\right)^{2}+\left(m_{j}^{N}-\overline{m^{N}}\right)^{2}$, the conclusion follows.

Proposition E.14. For all $N \geq 1$ and $T \geq 1$, there exists a constant $K$ depending only on $\lambda$ such that

$$
I E_{\theta}\left|\Upsilon_{T}^{N, 1,2,1}\right|^{2} \leq K N / T^{2}
$$

Proof. We have that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left|E_{\theta}\right|\left|\Upsilon_{T}^{N, 1,2,1}\right|^{2}=\frac{1}{T^{4}} \sum_{i, j=1}^{N} \operatorname{Cov}_{\theta}\left(\left(U_{i, T}\right)^{2},\left(U_{j, T}\right)^{2}\right) \\
& =\frac{1}{T^{4}} \sum_{i, j=1}^{N} \sum_{s=1}^{T} \sum_{t=1}^{T} \operatorname{Cov}_{\theta}\left(Y_{i, s} Y_{i, s}, Y_{j, t} Y_{j, t}\right)+\frac{1}{T^{4}} \sum_{i, j=1}^{N} \sum_{s \neq s^{\prime}} \sum_{t \neq t^{\prime}} \operatorname{Cov}_{\theta}\left(Y_{i, s} Y_{i, s^{\prime}}, Y_{j, t} Y_{j, t^{\prime}}\right) \\
& =: S_{1}+S_{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

By Lemma 3.8, Item 1 and Item 3, $S_{1} \leq K N / T^{3}$. To deal with $S_{2}$, we adapt the arguments of the proof of Lemma E.9. As before, write $\mathbf{z}=\left(z_{1}, z_{2}, z_{3}, z_{4}\right)$, and $B(\mathbf{z})=$ $\operatorname{Cov}_{\theta}\left[Y_{z_{1}} Y_{z_{2}}, Y_{z_{3}} Y_{z_{4}}\right]$. This expression is symmetric with respect to $t, t^{\prime}$ and also with respect to $s, s^{\prime}$. Now, introduce the set $F^{(2)}=\left\{\left(z_{1}, z_{2}\right): z_{1}=(i, s), z_{2}=\left(i, s^{\prime}\right), i \in\right.$ $\left.\{1, \ldots, N\}, s, s^{\prime} \in\{1, \ldots, T\}, s \neq s^{\prime}\right\}$ and define, for $p \in\{2,5,7\}, \mathcal{P}_{p, T}$ as the set of all vectors $\mathbf{z} \in F^{(2)} \times F^{(2)}$ satisfying the conditions of Item $p$ of Lemma 3.8. Moreover, notice that $\mathbf{z} \in \mathcal{P}_{5, T} \cup \mathcal{P}_{2, T}$ implies that the first coordinates (denoted $i$ and $j$ above) of the four couples in $\mathbf{z}$ are equal.

Then

$$
S_{2}=\frac{1}{T^{4}}\left|\sum_{\mathbf{z} \in \mathcal{P}_{7, T}} B(\mathbf{z})+\sum_{\mathbf{z} \in \mathcal{P}_{5, T}} B(\mathbf{z})+\sum_{\mathbf{z} \in \mathcal{P}_{2, T}} B(\mathbf{z})\right|
$$

Following Step 5 of the proof of Lemma E.9, it is easy so see that

$$
\sum_{\mathbf{z} \in \mathcal{P}_{7, T}} B(\mathbf{z}) \leq K T^{2}
$$

Moreover, Lemma 3.8, Item 5, implies that

$$
\sum_{\mathbf{z} \in \mathcal{P}_{5, T}} B(\mathbf{z}) \leq K T^{2}
$$

Finally,

$$
\sum_{\mathbf{z} \in \mathcal{P}_{2, T}} B(\mathbf{z}) \leq K\left|\mathcal{P}_{2, T}\right|=K N T^{2}
$$

All in all we therefore obtain that $S_{2} \leq K N / T^{2}$, implying the assertion.

# APPENDIX F: PROOF OF PROPOSITION 4.2 

This section contains a fine study of the random environment $\theta$. First, some matrix notation is introduced. Then, the asymptotics of the rows and columns of the rescaled random environment $A^{N}$ are stated in Lemma F.1. In turn, the asymptotics of the rows and columns of the inverse matrix $Q^{N}$ are stated in Lemmas F. 4 and F.6. Then, the proofs of these three lemmas are given in three disjoint subsections. Finally, the proof of Proposition 4.2 is given in the last subsection.

To readers interested in random environments that differ from the i.i.d. case, let us mention that the proof of Proposition 4.2 relies solely on the results of Lemmas F.1, F.4, and F. 6 in the sense that the same proof applies to any environment $\theta$ for which these lemmas hold. Similarly, the proofs of Lemmas F. 4 and F. 6 depend only on Lemma F. 1 Therefore, only the proof Lemma F. 1 must be adapted. In what follows, we specify the adaptation required for the symmetric interaction case.

The main modification concerns the bound of the variance terms for which we use Bienaymé's identity together with a control of the few non null covariance terms. The exhaustive list of modifications is: 1) Equation (96), 2) Equation (97) by proving that $\operatorname{Var}\left(\sum_{k \in \mathcal{P}_{n}} Z_{k}\right)$ and $\mathbb{E}\left[\left(\sum_{k \in \mathcal{P}_{n}} \theta_{1 j} Z_{j}\right)^{2}\right]$ are smaller than some universal constant, 3) check that the "independence argument" below Equation (98) still holds, 4) replace the "independence argument" by Cauchy-Schwarz inequality to bound $\mu_{1,1}, 5$ ) Equation (99) is replaced by

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[\left(Z_{i}\left(1-\left|\mathcal{P}_{a}\right|^{-1}\right)-\frac{1}{\left|\mathcal{P}_{a}\right|} \sum_{j \in \mathcal{P}_{n}: j \neq i} Z_{j}\right)^{2}\right] \leq\left(1-\left|\mathcal{P}_{a}\right|^{-1}\right) \operatorname{Var}\left(Z_{i}\right)+K N^{-2}
$$

for some universal constant $K$.
Two technical results used throughout the proofs are stated as technical lemmas in Section H.
F.1. General notation. Hereafter, for any subset $S$ of $[N]$, we write $1_{S}$ to indicate the $N$-dimensional vector having value 1 in each coordinate belonging to $S$ and value 0 in the remaining coordinates. To alleviate the notation, we will simply write $1_{N}$ and $0_{N}$ instead of $1_{[N]}$ and $1_{\emptyset}$, respectively. For any vector $v \in \mathbb{R}^{N}, \bar{v}=N^{-1} \sum_{i=1}^{N} v_{i}$ denotes the arithmetic mean of the coordinates of $v,\|v\|_{r}=\left(\sum_{i=1}^{N}\left|v_{i}\right|^{r}\right)^{1 / r}$ where $r \in[1, \infty)$, denotes the $r$-norm of $v$ and $\|v\|_{\infty}=\max _{1 \leq i \leq N}\left|v_{i}\right|$ its $\infty$-norm. For vectors $v, u \in \mathbb{R}^{N}$, we write $v \odot u$ to denote the vector whose $i$-th coordinate is $v_{i} u_{i}$, for $1 \leq i \leq N$. In other words, $v \odot u$ is the Hadamard product between the vectors $v$ and $u$. To shorten the notation, we will simply note $v^{2}$ instead of $v \odot v$. Observe that, with this notation, the orthogonal projection of a vector $v \in \mathbb{R}^{N}$ on the coordinates in $S \subseteq[N]$ can be written as $1_{S} \odot v$. In particular, all coordinates in $S^{c}$ of the vector $1_{S} \odot v$ are null. One can always write $v=1_{S} \odot v+1_{S^{c}} \odot v$.

For any $N$-by- $N$ matrix $B$ with real entries, we denote $B^{\dagger}$ its transpose. For all $r \in[1, \infty]$, we denote $\|B\|_{r}$ the operator norm of $B$ associated to the $r$-norm $\|\cdot\|_{r}$ :

$$
\|B\|_{r}=\sup _{v \in \mathbb{R}^{N}: v \neq 0_{N}} \frac{\|B v\|_{r}}{\|v\|_{r}}
$$

It is well-known that $\|B\|_{1}$ and $\|B\|_{\infty}$ may be defined alternatively as

$$
\|B\|_{1}=\max _{1 \leq j \leq N} \sum_{i=1}^{N}|B(i, j)| \text { and }\|B\|_{\infty}=\max _{1 \leq i \leq N} \sum_{j=1}^{N}|B(i, j)|
$$

The following fact will also be used in the sequel: for each $r \in(1, \infty)$, it holds that

$$
\|B\|_{r} \leq\|B\|_{1}^{1 / r}\|B\|_{\infty}^{1-1 / r}
$$

F.2. Study of the rescaled random environment. Recall that $A^{N}=\left(A^{N}(i, j)\right)_{1 \leq i, j \leq N}$ is a rescaled version of the random environment $\theta$ defined as, for each $1 \leq i \leq N$,

$$
A^{N}(i, j)=\left\{\begin{array}{l}
N^{-1} \theta_{i j}, \text { if } j \in \mathcal{P}_{+}, \\
-N^{-1} \theta_{i j}, \text { if } j \in \mathcal{P}_{-}
\end{array}\right.
$$

One can check that $\max \left\{\left\|A^{N}\right\|_{1},\left\|A^{N}\right\|_{\infty}\right\} \leq 1$, so that (72) implies that $\left\|A^{N}\right\|_{r} \leq 1$ for all $r \in(1, \infty)$ as well.

F.2.1. Notation. In what follows, for $a, b \in\{-,+\}$, we denote $L^{N, a b}=1_{\mathcal{P}_{a}} \odot A^{N} 1_{\mathcal{P}_{b}}$ and $C^{N, a b}=1_{\mathcal{P}_{a}} \odot\left(A^{N}\right)^{\top} 1_{\mathcal{P}_{b}}$, where $\left(A^{N}\right)^{\top}$ denotes the transpose of the matrix $A^{N}$. On the one hand, both vectors have null coordinates outside of the set $\mathcal{P}_{a}$. On the other hand, each coordinate $i \in \mathcal{P}_{a}$ of the random vector $L^{N, a b}$ (resp. $C^{N, a b}$ ) is obtained by summing the entries in $\mathcal{P}_{b}$ of the $i$-th row (resp. column) of the matrix $A^{N}$. Alternatively, the random vectors $L^{N, a b}$ and $C^{N, a b}$ can be defined as follows:

$$
L_{i}^{N, a b}=\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\sum_{j \in \mathcal{P}_{b}} A^{N}(i, j), \text { if } i \in \mathcal{P}_{a} \\
0, \text { otherwise }
\end{array}\right.
$$

and

$$
C_{i}^{N, a b}=\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\sum_{j \in \mathcal{P}_{b}} A^{N}(j, i), \text { if } i \in \mathcal{P}_{a} \\
0, \text { otherwise }
\end{array}\right.
$$

For $a \in\{-,+\}$, we denote $L^{N, a \bullet}=1_{\mathcal{P}_{a}} \odot A^{N} 1_{N}$ and $C^{N, a \bullet}=1_{\mathcal{P}_{a}} \odot\left(A^{N}\right)^{\top} 1_{N}$. Note that the coordinates not belonging to $\mathcal{P}_{a}$ of these two vectors are also 0 . Besides, each coordinate $i \in \mathcal{P}_{a}$ of the random vector $L^{N, a \bullet}$ (resp. $C^{N, a \bullet}$ ) is given by the sum over all entries of the $i$-th row (resp. column) of the matrix $A^{N}$. One can easily check that

$$
L^{N, a \bullet}=L^{N, a+}+L^{N, a-} \text { and } C^{N, a \bullet}=C^{N, a+}+C^{N, a-}
$$

so that the vectors $L^{N, a \bullet}$ and $C^{N, a \bullet}$ could be defined alternatively through these identities.
For $b \in\{-,+\}$, we denote $L^{N, \bullet b}=A^{N} 1_{\mathcal{P}_{b}}$ and $C^{N, \bullet b}=\left(A^{N}\right)^{\top} 1_{\mathcal{P}_{b}}$. Observe that each coordinate $1 \leq i \leq N$ of the random vector $L^{N, \bullet b}$ (resp. $C^{N, \bullet b}$ ) is given by the sum over the entries in $\mathcal{P}_{b}$ of the $i$-th row (resp. column) of the matrix $A^{N}$. One can also verify that

$$
L^{N, \bullet b}=L^{N,+b}+L^{N,-b} \text { and } C^{N, \bullet b}=C^{N,+b}+C^{N,-b}
$$

In the sequel, for each $a, b \in\{-,+\}$, let

$$
\widetilde{L}^{N, a b}=L^{N, a b}-\left(r_{a}^{N}\right)^{-1} \widetilde{L}^{N, a b} 1_{\mathcal{P}_{a}} \text { and } \widetilde{C}^{N, a b}=C^{N, a b}-\left(r_{a}^{N}\right)^{-1} \widetilde{C}^{N, a b} 1_{\mathcal{P}_{a}}
$$

The vectors $\widetilde{L}^{N, a b}$ and $\widetilde{C}^{N, a b}$ can be thought as the population-wise centered versions of the vectors $L^{N, a b}$ and $C^{N, a b}$ respectively, in the sense that $\widetilde{L}^{N, a b}=\widetilde{C}^{N, a b}=0$. Observe that these vectors are well-defined for all $N \geq 1$ such that $r_{a}^{N}>0$. In the next result, we collect some bounds which will be used throughout the section.
F.2.2. Convergence rates. In what follows, for $a, b \in\{-,+\}$, we write $\delta_{a b}$ to denote the Kronecker delta between $a$ and $b$.

LEMMA F.1. Let $a, b, a_{1}, b_{1} \in\{-,+\}$. The following inequalities hold for all $N \geq 1$ such that $r_{-}^{N} \wedge r_{+}^{N}>0$,

$$
\begin{gathered}
I E\left[\left|\left\langle\widetilde{L}^{N, a b}, \widetilde{L}^{N, a_{1} b_{1}}\right\rangle-\delta_{a a_{1}} \delta_{b b_{1}} r_{a} r_{b} p(1-p)\right|^{2}\right] \leq K N^{-1} \\
I E\left[\left\|A \widetilde{L}^{a b}\right\|_{2}^{2}\right] \leq K N^{-1} \\
I E\left[\max _{a, b \in\{-,+\}}\left\{\left|\left(r_{a}^{N} r_{b}^{N}\right)^{-1} \widetilde{L}^{N, a b}-(b p)\right|^{2} \vee\left|\left(r_{a}^{N} r_{b}^{N}\right)^{-1} \widetilde{C}^{N, a b}-(a p)\right|^{2}\right\}\right] \\
\leq K \max _{a, b}\left\{\left(r_{a}^{N} r_{b}^{N}\right)^{-1}\right\} N^{-2}, \text { and } \\
\left\|\widetilde{L}^{N, a b}\right\|_{2} \leq\left\|L^{N, a b}-\left(b p r_{b}^{N}\right) 1_{\mathcal{P}_{a}}\right\|_{2} \text { and }\left\|\widetilde{C}^{N, a b}\right\|_{2} \leq\left\|C^{N, a b}-\left(a p r_{b}^{N}\right) 1_{\mathcal{P}_{a}}\right\|_{2}
\end{gathered}
$$

where $K$ is some universal constant. Moreover, for each $\alpha \geq 1$, there exists a constant $K_{\alpha}$ depending only on $\alpha$ such that, for all $N \geq 1$ satisfying $r_{-}^{N} \wedge r_{+}^{N}>0$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \text { IE }\left[\max _{a, b \in\{-,+\}}\left\{\left\|L^{N, a b}-\left(b p r_{b}^{N}\right) 1_{\mathcal{P}_{a}}\right\|_{2}^{\alpha} \vee\left\|C^{N, a b}-\right.\right.\right.\right.\left.\left.\left.\left(a p r_{b}^{N}\right) 1_{\mathcal{P}_{a}}\right\|_{2}^{\alpha}\right\}\right] \\
& \leq K_{\alpha} \max _{a \in\{-,+\}}\left\{\left(r_{a}^{N} / r_{b}^{N}\right)^{\alpha / 2}\right\}
\end{aligned}
$$

The proof of Lemma F. 1 is postponed to Section F.4.
REMARK F.2. Let $a, b \in\{-,+\}$. Because of the relations (75) and (76), some statements of Lemma F. 1 admit immediate corollaries. For instance,

- $C^{N, \bullet b}=C^{N,+b}+C^{N,-b}$ and $\widetilde{C}^{N, \bullet b}=\widetilde{C}^{N,+b}+\widetilde{C}^{N,-b}$ are orthogonal sums, and in particular one can deduce from Equations (81) and (82) that

$$
I E\left[\left\|\widetilde{C}^{N, \bullet b}\right\|_{2}^{\alpha}\right] \leq I E\left[\left\|C^{N, \bullet b}-p r_{b}^{N}\left(1_{\mathcal{P}_{+}}-1_{\mathcal{P}_{-}}\right)\right\|_{2}^{\alpha}\right] \leq 2 K_{\alpha} \max _{a \in\{-,+\}}\left\{\left(r_{a}^{N} / r_{b}^{N}\right)^{\alpha / 2}\right\}
$$

- or, $L^{N, a \bullet}=L^{N, a+}+L^{N, a-}$ and $\widetilde{L}^{N, a \bullet}=\widetilde{L}^{N, a+}+\widetilde{L}^{N, a-}$, and in particular one can deduce from Equations (81) and (82) that

$$
\left\|\widetilde{L}^{N, a \bullet}\right\|_{2} \leq\left\|L^{N, a+}-p r_{+}^{N} 1_{\mathcal{P}_{a}}\right\|_{2}+\left\|L^{N, a-}+p r_{-}^{N} 1_{\mathcal{P}_{a}}\right\|_{2}
$$

and

$$
I E\left[\left\|L^{N, a \bullet}-p\left(r_{+}^{N}-r_{-}^{N}\right) 1_{\mathcal{P}_{a}}\right\|_{2}^{\alpha}\right] \leq K_{\alpha}^{\prime} \max _{a \in\{-,+\}}\left\{\left(r_{a}^{N} / r_{b}^{N}\right)^{\alpha / 2}\right\}
$$

for some $K_{\alpha}^{\prime}$ which may be different from $K_{\alpha}$.
F.3. Results regarding the inverse matrix. Recall that $\lambda>0$. Under this condition, the random matrix $Q^{N}:=\left(I-(1-\lambda) A^{N}\right)^{-1}=\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}(1-\lambda)^{n}\left(A^{N}\right)^{n}$ is well-defined and satisfies $\left\|Q^{N}\right\|_{r} \leq \lambda^{-1}$ for all $r \in[1, \infty]$. For later use, let us observe that the easy-to-check properties $\left\|\left(Q^{N}\right)^{\top}\right\|_{1}=\left\|Q^{N}\right\|_{\infty}$ and $\left\|\left(Q^{N}\right)^{\top}\right\|_{\infty}=\left\|Q^{N}\right\|_{1}$ combined with inequality (72) imply that $\left\|\left(Q^{N}\right)^{\top}\right\|_{r} \leq \lambda^{-1}$ for any $r \in[1, \infty]$.

As suggested by the heuristics presented in Section 2, a crucial ingredient in our analysis is to study both the sum of rows and columns of the matrix $Q^{N}$. By definition of the matrix $Q^{N}$ itself, these quantities are related to the corresponding counterparts computed from the matrix $A^{N}$.
F.3.1. Notation. Similarly as above, for $a, b \in\{-,+\}$, let us denote $\ell^{N, a b}$ (resp. $c^{N, a b}$ ) the random vector obtained by summing, for each row (resp. column) in $\mathcal{P}_{a}$ of the random matrix $Q^{N}$, the entries in $\mathcal{P}_{b}$. Also, we denote $\ell^{N, a \bullet}=\ell^{N, a+}+\ell^{N, a-}$ and $\ell^{N, \bullet b}=\ell^{N,+b}+$ $\ell^{N,-b}$ for $a, b \in\{-,+\}$, and define $\ell^{N}=\ell^{N,+\bullet}+\ell^{N,-\bullet}$. Note that $\ell^{N}=Q^{N} 1_{N}$, i.e., $\ell^{N}$ corresponds to the random vector obtained by summing the rows of $Q^{N}$. The vectors $c^{N, \bullet a}$, $c^{N, \bullet a}$ and $c^{N}$ are defined in a similar way. In particular, note that $c^{N}=\left(Q^{N}\right)^{\top} 1_{N}$ is given as the sum of the columns of $Q^{N}$. Here $\left(Q^{N}\right)^{\top}$ denotes the transpose of the matrix $Q^{N}$. For later use, let us also observe that $\widetilde{\ell^{N}}=\widetilde{c^{N}}$.

Like we did for $L$ and $C$, we define, for each $a, b \in\{-,+\}$

$$
\widetilde{\ell}^{N, a b}=\ell^{N, a b}-\left(r_{a}^{N}\right)^{-1} \overline{\ell^{N, a b}} 1_{\mathcal{P}_{a}} \text { and } \widetilde{c}^{N, a b}=c^{N, a b}-\left(r_{a}^{N}\right)^{-1} \overline{c^{N, a b}} 1_{\mathcal{P}_{a}}
$$

Moreover, we denote $\widetilde{\ell}^{N, a \bullet}=\widetilde{\ell}^{N, a+}+\widetilde{\ell}^{N, a-}, \widetilde{\ell}^{N, \bullet b}=\widetilde{\ell}^{N,+b}+\widetilde{\ell}^{N,-b}$ for $a, b \in\{-,+\}$, and $\widetilde{\ell}^{N}=\widetilde{\ell}^{N,+\bullet}+\widetilde{\ell}^{N,-\bullet}$.

Here is an immediate result stating that the $\ell$ and $c$ vectors are uniformly bounded.

LEMMA F.3. Assume that $1 \geq \lambda>0$. Then,

$$
\max \left\{\max _{a, b \in\{-,+\}}\left\{\left\|\ell^{N, a b}\right\|_{\infty},\left\|c^{N, a b}\right\|_{\infty}\right\},\left\|\ell^{N}\right\|_{\infty},\left\|c^{N}\right\|_{\infty}\right\} \leq \lambda^{-1}
$$

Proof. To show (84), first observe that

$$
\max _{1 \leq i \leq N} \max \left\{\max _{a, b \in\{-,+\}}\left\{\left|\ell_{i}^{N, a b}\right|,\left|c_{i}^{N, a b}\right|\right\},\left|\ell_{i}^{N}\right|,\left|c_{i}^{N}\right|\right\} \leq \max \left\{\left\|Q^{N}\right\|_{1},\left\|Q^{N}\right\|_{\infty}\right\}
$$

and then use the fact that $\max \left\{\left\|Q^{N}\right\|_{1},\left\|Q^{N}\right\|_{\infty}\right\} \leq \lambda^{-1}$.
F.3.2. Convergence rates. Recall that $\delta_{a b}$ denotes the Kronecker delta between $a$ and $b$.

Lemma F.4. Assume that $1 \geq \lambda>0$. There exists a constant $K>0$ which depends on $\lambda$ such that for all $N \geq 1$ and $a, b \in\{-,+\}$, it holds that

$$
\begin{gathered}
I E\left[\left|\widetilde{\ell}^{N, a b}-\frac{r_{a} \delta_{a b}+b(1-\lambda) p r_{+} r_{-}}{1-(1-\lambda) p\left(r_{+}-r_{-}\right)}\right|^{2}\right] \leq \frac{K}{N^{2}} \\
I E\left[\left|\widetilde{c^{N, a \bullet}}-r_{a} \frac{\left[1+(2 a)(1-\lambda) p\left(1-r_{a}\right)\right]}{1-(1-\lambda) p\left(r_{+}-r_{-}\right)}\right|^{2}\right] \leq \frac{K}{N^{2}} \\
I E\left[\left\|\widetilde{\ell}^{N, \bullet b}\right\|_{2}^{4}\right] \leq K \text { and } \operatorname{IE}\left[\left\|\widetilde{c}^{N, \bullet b}\right\|_{2}^{4}\right] \leq K \\
I E\left[\left\|\widetilde{\ell}^{N, \bullet b}\right\|_{2}^{2}-\frac{(1-\lambda)^{2} p(1-p)\left[r_{b}+(1-\lambda) p r_{+} r_{-}(2 b+(1-\lambda) p)\right]}{(1-(1-\lambda) p\left(r_{+}-r_{-}\right))^{2}}\right]\right] \leq \frac{K}{\sqrt{N}} \\
I E\left[\left\|\widetilde{\ell}^{N}\right\|_{2}^{2}-\frac{(1-\lambda)^{2} p(1-p)}{\left(1-(1-\lambda) p\left(r_{+}-r_{-}\right)\right)^{2}}\right]\right] \leq \frac{K}{\sqrt{N}}
\end{gathered}
$$

Remark F.5. First, notice that Remark F. 2 also applies to Lemma F. 4 (with $L$ and $C$ replaced by $\ell$ and $c$ ).

For later use, let us observe that an immediate consequence of Equation (85) is that there exists a constant $K>0$ such that $N \geq 1$,

$$
I E\left[\left|\widetilde{\ell^{N}}-\frac{1}{1-(1-\lambda) p\left(r_{+}-r_{-}\right)}\right|^{2}\right] \leq \frac{K}{N^{2}}
$$

The proof of Lemma F. 4 is postponed to Section F.5.
The following lemma gives a way to control the $l^{2}$ norms of the fully centered vectors by the population wise centered vectors.

Lemma F.6. Assume that $1 \geq \lambda>0$. There exists a constant $K>0$ which depends on $\lambda$ such that for all $N \geq 1$ such that $r_{+}^{N} \wedge r_{-}^{N}>0$, it holds that

$$
\begin{gathered}
I E\left[\left\|\left\|\ell^{N}-\overline{\ell^{N}} 1_{N}\right\|_{2}^{2}-\left\|\widetilde{\ell}^{N}\right\|_{2}^{2}\right]\right] \leq \frac{K}{N} \\
I E\left[\left|\left\langle\ell^{N}-\overline{\ell^{N}} 1_{N},(1-\lambda)^{2}\left(Q^{N} L^{N, \bullet-}-\overline{Q^{N} L^{N, \bullet-}}\right)\right\rangle-\left\langle\overline{\ell}^{N}, \overline{\ell}^{N, \bullet-}\right\rangle\right|\right] \leq K N^{-1} \\
I E\left[\left|(1-\lambda)\left\|Q L^{N, \bullet}-\overline{Q^{N} L^{N, \bullet-}}\right\|_{2}^{2}-\left\|\overline{\ell}^{N, \bullet-}\right\|_{2}^{2}\right]\right] \leq K N^{-1}
\end{gathered}
$$

The proof of Lemma F. 6 is postponed to Section F.6.

F.4. Proof of Lemma F.1. Before the proof, we recall some classical results in the three lemmas below.

Lemma F.7. Consider i.i.d. random variables $\left(B_{i}\right)_{1 \leq i \leq N}$ distributed as $\operatorname{Ber}(p)$ with $p \in[0,1]$ and let $\bar{B}=N^{-1} \sum_{i=1}^{N} B_{i}$. Then, for each $\alpha \geq 1$ there exists a constant $C_{\alpha}>0$ depending only on $\alpha$ such that

$$
I E\left[|\bar{B}-p|^{\alpha}\right] \leq C_{\alpha} N^{-\alpha / 2}
$$

Proof. Hoeffding's inequality implies that for any $x>0$,

$$
I F(|\bar{B}-p| \geq x) \leq 2 e^{-2 x^{2} N}
$$

Now, using the tail sum formula for the expectation one can show that

$$
I E\left[|\bar{B}-p|^{\alpha}\right] \leq 2 \alpha \int_{0}^{\infty} x^{\alpha-1} e^{-2 x^{2} N} d x=\alpha \sqrt{\frac{2 \pi}{N}} I E\left[Z^{\alpha-1} 1_{Z>0}\right]
$$

where $Z \sim \mathcal{N}\left(0,(4 N)^{-1}\right)$. Finally, by observing that $Y=(4 N)^{1 / 2} Z \sim \mathcal{N}(0,1)$, it follows that

$$
\alpha \sqrt{\frac{2 \pi}{N}} I E\left[Z^{\alpha-1} 1_{Z>0}\right]=\alpha \frac{\sqrt{2 \pi}}{2^{\alpha-1}} N^{-\alpha / 2} I E\left[Y^{\alpha-1} 1_{Y>0}\right]
$$

and the result follows.
LemmA F.8. Let $\left(B_{i j}\right)_{1 \leq i, j \leq N}$ be i.i.d. random variables distributed as $\operatorname{Ber}(p)$ with $p \in$ $[0,1]$. For $U, V \subset[N]$ and $\epsilon \in\{-1,1\}$, define $W_{i}=\epsilon N^{-1} \sum_{j \in V} B_{i j}$ for $i \in U$, and $W_{i}=0$, for $i \in U^{c}$. Denote $W=\left(W_{1}, \ldots, W_{N}\right)$. Then, for any $\alpha \geq 1$, there exists a constant $K_{\alpha}>0$ depending only on $\alpha$ such that

$$
I E\left(\left\|W-p \epsilon\right\| V\left|N^{-1} 1_{U}\right\|_{2}^{\alpha}\right) \leq K_{\alpha}\left(\frac{|U|}{|V|}\right)^{\alpha / 2}
$$

Proof. Jensen inequality combined with Lemma F. 7 and the fact that $|V| / N \leq 1$ implies that for any $\alpha \geq 1$,

$$
I E\left[\left\|W-p \epsilon\right\| V\left|N^{-1} 1_{U}\right\|_{2}^{2 \alpha}\right] \leq|U|^{\alpha}\left(|V| N^{-1}\right)^{2 \alpha}\left(C_{2 \alpha}|V|^{-(2 \alpha) / 2}\right) \leq C_{2 \alpha}\left(\frac{|U|}{|V|}\right)^{\alpha}
$$

where the constant $C_{2 \alpha}$ is the one of Lemma F.7. By using Jensen inequality once more, we deduce that

$$
I E\left[\left\|W-p \epsilon\right\| V\left|N^{-1} 1_{U}\right\|_{2}^{\alpha}\right] \leq\left(I E\left[\left\|W-p \epsilon\right\| V\left|N^{-1} 1_{U}\right\|_{2}^{2 \alpha}\right]\right)^{1 / 2}
$$

and the result follows, putting $K_{\alpha}:=C_{2 \alpha}^{1 / 2}$.
Lemma F.9. Consider a vector $v=\left(v_{1}, \ldots, v_{N}\right) \in \mathbb{R}^{N}$ supported on $S \subseteq\{1, \ldots, N\}$. For any $\xi \in \mathbb{R}$, the following inequality holds:

$$
\left\|v-\frac{N}{|S|} \bar{v} 1_{S}\right\|_{2} \leq\left\|v-\xi 1_{S}\right\|_{2}
$$

where $\bar{v}=N^{-1} \sum_{i=1}^{N} v_{i}=N^{-1} \sum_{i \in S} v_{i}$.

Proof. Consider $U \sim \operatorname{Unif}\left(\left\{v_{i}: i \in S\right\}\right)$, and observe that $I E[U]=\bar{v} N|S|^{-1}$ and $\operatorname{Var}(U)=|S|^{-1}\left\|v-N|S|^{-1} \bar{v} 1_{S}\right\|_{2}$. Since $\operatorname{Var}(U)=\inf _{\xi \in \mathbb{R}} I E\left[(U-\xi)^{2}\right]$, it follows that for any $\xi \in \mathbb{R}$,

$$
|S|^{-1}\left\|v-\frac{N}{|S|} \bar{v} 1_{S}\right\|_{2} \leq I E\left[(U-\xi)^{2}\right]=|S|^{-1}\left\|v-\xi 1_{S}\right\|_{2}
$$

implying the result.
Proof of Lemma F.1. Inequalities (81) and (82) follow from Lemmas F. 9 and F. 8 respectively. Next, we prove Inequality (80). First, note that $\left(r_{a}^{N} r_{b}^{N}\right)^{-1} \overline{L^{N, a b}}-(b p)=$ $b\left(\left|\mathcal{P}_{a}\right|\left|\mathcal{P}_{b}\right|\right)^{-1} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{P}_{a}} \sum_{j \in \mathcal{P}_{b}}\left(\theta_{i j}-p\right)$, so that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& I E\left[\left|\left(r_{a}^{N} r_{b}^{N}\right)^{-1} \overline{L^{N, a b}}-(b p)\right|^{2}\right]=\operatorname{Var}\left(\left(\left|\mathcal{P}_{a}\right|\left|\mathcal{P}_{b}\right|\right)^{-1} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{P}_{a}} \sum_{j \in \mathcal{P}_{b}} \theta_{i j}\right) \\
& =p(1-p)\left(\left|\mathcal{P}_{a}\right|\left|\mathcal{P}_{b}\right|\right)^{-1}=N^{-2} p(1-p)\left(r_{a}^{N} r_{b}^{N}\right)^{-1}
\end{aligned}
$$

Since $p(1-p) \leq 1 / 4$, we conclude that

$$
I E\left[\left|\left(r_{a}^{N} r_{b}^{N}\right)^{-1} \overline{L^{N, a b}}-(b p)\right|^{2}\right] \leq\left(N^{-2} / 4\right) \max _{c, d}\left\{\left(r_{c}^{N} r_{d}^{N}\right)^{-1}\right\}
$$

Similar arguments can be applied to show that

$$
I E\left[\left|\left(r_{a}^{N} r_{b}^{N}\right)^{-1} \overline{C^{N, a b}}-(a p)\right|^{2}\right] \leq\left(N^{-2} / 4\right) \max _{c, d}\left\{\left(r_{c}^{N} r_{d}^{N}\right)^{-1}\right\}
$$

Inequality (80) follows then from the above inequalities and from the fact that $x \vee y \leq x+y$ for any $x, y \geq 0$.

We now establish Inequality (79). To that end, first observe that

$$
I E\left[\left\|A^{N} \widetilde{L}^{N, a b}\right\|_{2}^{2}\right]=N I E\left[\left(\sum_{j \in \mathcal{P}_{a}} A^{N}(1, j) \widetilde{L}_{j}^{N, a b}\right)^{2}\right]
$$

Next, observe that if we denote $Z_{j}=L_{j}^{N, a b}-(p b) r_{b}^{N}$ for $j \in \mathcal{P}_{a}$, then we can write (recall that $A^{N}(i, j)=b N^{-1} \theta_{i j}$ for $1 \leq i \leq N$ and $\left.j \in \mathcal{P}_{b}\right)$,

$$
\left[\sum_{j \in \mathcal{P}_{a}} A^{N}(1, j) \widetilde{L}_{j}^{N, a b}\right]^{2}=N^{-2}\left[\sum_{j \in \mathcal{P}_{a}} \theta_{1 j} Z_{j}-\left(\sum_{j \in \mathcal{P}_{a}} \theta_{1 j}\right)\left(\left|\mathcal{P}_{a}\right|^{-1} \sum_{k \in \mathcal{P}_{a}} Z_{k}\right)\right]^{2}
$$

so that by applying Jensen's inequality we obtain that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left.I E\left[\left\|A^{N} \widetilde{L}^{N, a b}\right\|_{2}^{2}\right] \leq\right. \\
& \left.2 N^{-1}\left[I E\left[\left(\sum_{j \in \mathcal{P}_{a}} \theta_{1 j} Z_{j}\right)^{2}\right]+I E\left[\left(\sum_{j \in \mathcal{P}_{a}} \theta_{1 j}\right)^{2}\left(\left|\mathcal{P}_{a}\right|^{-1} \sum_{k \in \mathcal{P}_{a}} Z_{k}\right)^{2}\right]\right]\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

By observing that $\sum_{j \in \mathcal{P}_{a}} \theta_{1 j} \leq\left|\mathcal{P}_{a}\right|$ and using that $\left(Z_{k}\right)_{k \in \mathcal{P}_{b}}$ are i.i.d. centered random variables, one can check that

$$
\begin{aligned}
I E\left[\left(\sum_{j \in \mathcal{P}_{a}} \theta_{1 j}\right)^{2}\left(\left|\mathcal{P}_{a}\right|^{-1} \sum_{k \in \mathcal{P}_{a}} Z_{k}\right)^{2}\right] & \leq\left|\mathcal{P}_{a}\right|^{2} \operatorname{Var}\left(\left|\mathcal{P}_{a}\right|^{-1} \sum_{k \in \mathcal{P}_{a}} Z_{k}\right) \\
& =\left|\mathcal{P}_{a}\right| \operatorname{Var}\left(Z_{1}\right)=r_{a}^{N} r_{b}^{N} p(1-p) \leq 1 / 4
\end{aligned}
$$

where in the last inequality we have used that $\operatorname{Var}\left(Z_{k}\right)=\operatorname{Var}\left(L_{k}^{N, a b}\right)=\left|\mathcal{P}_{b}\right| p(1-p) / N^{2}$.
Now, note that if $j \neq 1$, then $\theta_{1 j}$ is independent of $Z_{j}$ so that $I E\left[\theta_{1 j} Z_{j}\right]=I E\left[\theta_{1 j}\right] I E\left[Z_{j}\right]=$ 0 , because $Z_{j}$ is centered. Moreover, one can check that $\left(\theta_{1 j} Z_{j}\right)_{j \in \mathcal{P}_{a}: j \neq 1}$ are independent. Hence, by combining these facts with Jensen's inequality, we can deduce that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& I E\left[\left(\sum_{j \in \mathcal{P}_{a}} \theta_{1 j} Z_{j}\right)^{2}\right] \leq 2\left[I E\left[\left(\sum_{j \in \mathcal{P}_{a}: j \neq 1} \theta_{1 j} Z_{j}\right)^{2}\right]+I E\left[\left(\theta_{11} Z_{1}\right)^{2}\right]\right] \\
& \leq 2\left[\operatorname{Var}\left(\sum_{j \in \mathcal{P}_{a}: j \neq 1} \theta_{1 j} Z_{j}\right)+\operatorname{Var}\left(Z_{1}\right)\right] \\
& \leq 2\left[\left(\left|\mathcal{P}_{a}\right|-1\right) p \operatorname{Var}\left(Z_{1}\right)+\operatorname{Var}\left(Z_{1}\right)\right] \leq 2 r_{a}^{N} r_{b}^{N} p(1-p) \leq 1 / 2
\end{aligned}
$$

Combining the last three inequalities we show that Inequality (79) holds.
It remains to show Inequality (78). In the case $a_{1} \neq a$, the two vectors $\widetilde{L}^{N, a b}$ and $\widetilde{L}^{N, a b_{1}}$ have disjoint supports so that $\left\langle\widetilde{L}^{N, a b}, \widetilde{L}^{N, a_{1} b_{1}}\right\rangle=0$ a.s. and (79) trivially holds.

From now on, consider that $a_{1}=a$. Let us denote $Y_{a, b b_{1}}^{N}=\left\langle\widetilde{L}^{N, a b}, \widetilde{L}^{N, a b_{1}}\right\rangle$ and prove that there exists a universal constant $K$ such that

$$
I E\left[\left|Y_{a, b b_{1}}^{N}-\delta_{b b_{1}} r_{a} r_{b} p(1-p)\right|^{2}\right] \leq K\left[I E\left[\left|Y_{a, b b_{1}}^{N}-I E\left[Y_{a, b b_{1}}^{N}\right]\right|^{2}\right]+N^{-2}\right]
$$

First, consider the case $b_{1} \neq b$. Remind that $L^{N, a b}$ only depends on $\left\{\theta_{i j}, i \in \mathcal{P}_{a}, j \in \mathcal{P}_{b}\right\}$, and remark that $I E\left[\widetilde{L}_{i}^{N, a b}\right]=0$ for all $i=1, \ldots, N$. In particular, the vectors $L^{N, a b}$ and $L^{N, a b_{1}}$ are independent and

$$
I E\left[Y_{a, b b_{1}}^{N}\right]=\left\langle I E\left[\widetilde{L}^{N, a b}\right], I E\left[\widetilde{L}^{N, a b_{1}}\right]\right\rangle=0
$$

so that

$$
I E\left[\left|Y_{a, b b_{1}}^{N}-\delta_{b b_{1}} r_{a} r_{b} p(1-p)\right|^{2}\right]=I E\left[\left|Y_{a, b b_{1}}^{N}-I E\left[Y_{a, b b_{1}}^{N}\right]\right|^{2}\right]
$$

Now, consider the case $b_{1}=b$. In that case, $Y_{a, b b_{1}}^{N}=\left\|\widetilde{L}^{N, a b}\right\|_{2}^{2}$, and observe that

$$
I E\left[\left\|\widetilde{L}^{N, a b}\right\|_{2}^{2}\right]=\left|\mathcal{P}_{a}\right| I E\left[\left(L_{i}^{N, a b}-\frac{1}{\left|\mathcal{P}_{a}\right|} \sum_{j \in \mathcal{P}_{a}} L_{j}^{N, a b}\right)^{2}\right]
$$

for any fixed $i \in \mathcal{P}_{a}$. In the rest of the proof, $i$ denotes an arbitrary index in $\mathcal{P}_{a}$. Next, observe that if we denote $Z_{j}=L_{j}^{N, a b}-(p b) r_{b}^{N}$ for $j \in \mathcal{P}_{a}$, then we can write

$$
I E\left[\left\|\widetilde{L}^{N, a b}\right\|_{2}^{2}\right]=\left|\mathcal{P}_{a}\right| I E\left[\left(Z_{i}\left(1-\left|\mathcal{P}_{a}\right|^{-1}\right)-\frac{1}{\left|\mathcal{P}_{a}\right|} \sum_{j \in \mathcal{P}_{a}: j \neq i} Z_{j}\right)^{2}\right]
$$

Since $\left(Z_{j}\right)_{j \in \mathcal{P}_{a}}$ are i.i.d. centered random variables, one can check that

$$
I E\left[\left(Z_{i}\left(1-\left|\mathcal{P}_{a}\right|^{-1}\right)-\frac{1}{\left|\mathcal{P}_{a}\right|} \sum_{j \in \mathcal{P}_{a}, j \neq i} Z_{j}\right)^{2}\right]=\left(1-\left|\mathcal{P}_{a}\right|^{-1}\right) \operatorname{Var}\left(Z_{i}\right)
$$

which, in turn, implies that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& I E\left[\left\|\widetilde{L}^{N, a b}\right\|_{2}^{2}\right]=\left|\mathcal{P}_{a}\right|\left(1-\left|\mathcal{P}_{a}\right|^{-1}\right) \operatorname{Var}\left(Z_{i}\right) \\
& =\left|\mathcal{P}_{a}\right|\left(1-\left|\mathcal{P}_{a}\right|^{-1}\right) \operatorname{Var}\left(L_{i}^{N, a b}\right)=r_{a}^{N} r_{b}^{N} p(1-p)-N^{-1} r_{b}^{N} p(1-p)
\end{aligned}
$$

Combining the above identity with Jensen's inequality (and the assumption we made on the sequence of fractions $r_{a}^{N}$ ), we deduce that Equation (98) is satisfied.

Next, notice that $\left(\left|\mathcal{P}_{a}\right|-1\right)^{-1} Y_{a, b b_{1}}^{N}$ can be seen as the empirical covariance of the random variables $L_{i}^{N, a b}$ and $L_{i}^{N, a b_{1}}, i \in \mathcal{P}_{a}$. In this perspective, $I E\left[\left|Y_{a, b b_{1}}^{N}-I E\left[Y_{a, b b_{1}}^{N}\right]\right|^{2}\right]$ corresponds to $\left(\left|\mathcal{P}_{a}\right|-1\right)^{2}$ times the variance of the empirical covariance of the random variables $L_{i}^{N, a b}$ and $L_{i}^{N, a b_{1}}, i \in \mathcal{P}_{a}$. It is well-known (e.g., see (Casella and Berger, 2024, page 363, exercise 7.45 b ) for the case of the empirical variance) that the latter is equal to

$$
\left|\mathcal{P}_{a}\right|^{-1}\left(\mu_{2,2}+\frac{\mu_{2,0} \mu_{0,2}-\left(\left|\mathcal{P}_{a}\right|-2\right) \mu_{1,1}^{2}}{\left|\mathcal{P}_{a}\right|-1}\right)
$$

where $\mu_{r, s}=I E\left[\left(L_{i}^{N, a b}-I E\left[L_{i}^{N, a b}\right]\right)^{r}\left(L_{i}^{N, a b_{1}}-I E\left[L_{i}^{N, a b_{1}}\right]\right)^{s}\right]$. We have $\mu_{2,2}=I E\left[\left(L_{i}^{N, a b}-\right.\right.$ $\left.b p r_{b}^{N}\right)^{2}\left(L_{i}^{N, a b_{1}}-b_{1} p r_{b_{1}}^{N}\right)^{2}\left[\leq\left(I E\left[\left(L_{i}^{N, a b}-b p r_{b}^{N}\right)^{4}\right] I E\left[\left(L_{i}^{N, a b_{1}}-b_{1} p r_{b_{1}}^{N}\right)^{4}\right]\right)^{1 / 2}\right.$ by Cauchy Schwarz inequality, $\mu_{2,0}=I E\left[\left(L_{i}^{N, a b}-b p r_{b}^{N}\right)^{2}\right], \mu_{0,2}=I E\left[\left(L_{i}^{N, a b_{1}}-b_{1} p r_{b_{1}}^{N}\right)^{2}\right]$ and $\mu_{1,1}=$ $\delta_{b b_{1}} I E\left[\left(L_{i}^{N, a b}-b p r_{b}^{N}\right)^{2}\right]$ by independence. By applying Lemma F.7, we know that, for some universal constant $K, \mu_{2,2} \leq K N^{-2}$ and $\mu_{2,0}+\mu_{0,2}+\mu_{1,1} \leq K N^{-1}$. Finally,

$$
I E\left[\left|Y_{a, b b_{1}}^{N}-I E\left[Y_{a, b b_{1}}^{N}\right]\right|^{2}\right] \leq K \frac{\left(\left|\mathcal{P}_{a}\right|-1\right)^{2}}{\left|\mathcal{P}_{a}\right|}\left(N^{-2}+\frac{N^{-2}-\left(\left|\mathcal{P}_{a}\right|-2\right) N^{-2}}{\left|\mathcal{P}_{a}\right|-1}\right) \leq K N^{-1}
$$

which implies the result.
F.5. Proof of Lemma F.4. It suffices to show that the inequalities hold for all $N$ sufficiently large. Recall that $r_{a}^{N}=\left|\mathcal{P}_{a}\right| / N$, for $a \in\{-,+\}$. Throughout the proof, we assume that $N$ is large enough $\left(N \geq N_{0}\right)$ ensuring that $r_{+}^{N} \wedge r_{-}^{N} \geq r_{\min }>0$ for some $r_{\min }$ sufficiently small depending only on the choice of $r_{+}$and $r_{-}$. In what follows, we shall denote $K$ a constant which may depend on $\lambda$ and which may change from one line to another. The proof is divided in the 12 steps below.

Step 1. Consider the event

$$
\mathcal{A}_{N}=\bigcap_{a \in\{-,+\}} \bigcap_{b \in\{-,+\}}\left\{\left\|L^{N, a b}-\left(b p r_{b}^{N}\right) 1_{\mathcal{P}_{a}}\right\|_{2} \vee\left\|C^{N, a b}-\left(a p r_{b}^{N}\right) 1_{\mathcal{P}_{a}}\right\|_{2} \leq N^{1 / 4}\right\}
$$

For later use, let us observe that Points (ii) and (iii) of Lemma F. 1 imply that $\mathcal{A}_{N}$ is included in the event

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathcal{G}_{N}=\bigcap_{b \in\{-,+\}}\{ \| L^{N, \bullet b}-(b p r_{b}^{N}) 1_{N} \|_{2} \vee\left\|L^{N, b \bullet}-p\left(r_{+}^{N}-r_{-}^{N}\right) 1_{\mathcal{P}_{b}}\right\|_{2} \\
\vee\left\|C^{N, \bullet b}-p r_{b}^{N}\left(1_{\mathcal{P}_{+}}-1_{\mathcal{P}_{-}}\right)\right\|_{2} \vee\left\|C^{N, b \bullet}-(b p) 1_{\mathcal{P}_{b}}\right\|_{2} \leq 2 N^{1 / 4}\}
\end{aligned}
$$

Combining Point (iv) of Lemma F. 1 with Markov's inequality, one can show that for any $\alpha \geq 1$, there exits a constant $K_{\alpha}>0$ such that

$$
I^{2}\left(\mathcal{G}_{N}\right) \geq I^{2}\left(\mathcal{A}_{N}\right) \geq 1-K_{\alpha} N^{-\alpha / 4}
$$

Hence, $\mathcal{A}_{N}$ is a large probability event and we will first consider the expectations appearing in Lemma F. 4 under the event $\mathcal{A}_{N}$ only. This is used in Step 4.

Step 2. Let $a, b \in\{-,+\}$. Here, we prove that
(i) $\widetilde{\ell}^{N, a b}=(1-\lambda)\left[1_{\mathcal{P}_{a}} \odot A^{N} \widetilde{\ell}^{N, \bullet b}+\sum_{e \in\{-,+\}}\left(r_{e}^{N}\right)^{-1} \overline{\ell^{N, e b} L}^{N, a e}+e^{N, a b} 1_{\mathcal{P}_{a}}\right]$,
where
(ii) $\left|\epsilon^{N, a b}\right| \leq\left(r_{a}^{N} N\right)^{-1}\left\|C^{N, \bullet a}-p r_{a}\left(1_{\mathcal{P}_{+}}-1_{\mathcal{P}_{-}}\right)\right\|_{2}\left\|\widetilde{\ell}^{N, \bullet b}\right\|_{2}$.

Starting from $\ell^{N, \bullet b}=Q^{N} 1_{\mathcal{P}_{b}}=\left(I_{N}-(1-\lambda) A^{N}\right)^{-1} 1_{\mathcal{P}_{b}}$, we get $\ell^{N, \bullet b}=1_{\mathcal{P}_{b}}+(1-$ $\lambda) A^{N} \ell^{N, \bullet b}$. Hence, it implies that $\ell^{N, a b}=1_{\mathcal{P}_{a}} \odot\left(1_{\mathcal{P}_{b}}+(1-\lambda) A^{N} \ell^{N, \bullet b}\right)$ and $\left(r_{a}^{N}\right)^{-1} \overline{\ell^{N, a b}}=$ $\delta_{a b}+(1-\lambda)\left(r_{a}^{N} N\right)^{-1}\left\langle A^{N} \ell^{N, \bullet b}, 1_{\mathcal{P}_{a}}\right\rangle$, so that

$$
\widetilde{\ell}^{N, a b}=(1-\lambda)\left[1_{\mathcal{P}_{a}} \odot A^{N} \ell^{N, \bullet b}-\left(r_{a}^{N} N\right)^{-1}\left\langle A^{N} \ell^{N, \bullet b}, 1_{\mathcal{P}_{a}}\right\rangle 1_{\mathcal{P}_{a}}\right]
$$

Then, using the substitution $\ell^{N, \bullet b}=\widetilde{\ell}^{N, \bullet b}+\sum_{e \in\{-,+\}}\left(r_{e}^{N}\right)^{-1} \overline{\ell^{N, e b}} 1_{\mathcal{P}_{e}}$ in the two terms above and the fact that $1_{\mathcal{P}_{a}} \odot A^{N} 1_{\mathcal{P}_{e}}=L^{N, a e}$, we get point (i) with

$$
\epsilon^{N, a b}=-\left(r_{a}^{N} N\right)^{-1}\left\langle A^{N} \widetilde{\ell}^{N, \bullet b}, 1_{\mathcal{P}_{a}}\right\rangle=-\left(r_{a}^{N} N\right)^{-1}\left\langle\widetilde{\ell}^{N, \bullet b},\left(A^{N}\right)^{\top} 1_{\mathcal{P}_{a}}\right\rangle
$$

Yet, $\left(A^{N}\right)^{\top} 1_{\mathcal{P}_{a}}=C^{N, \bullet a}$ by definition and $\left\langle\widetilde{\ell}^{N, \bullet b}, 1_{\mathcal{P}_{+}}\right\rangle=\left\langle\widetilde{\ell}^{N, \bullet b}, 1_{\mathcal{P}_{-}}\right\rangle=0$ by construction so that

$$
\epsilon^{N, a b}=-\left(r_{a}^{N} N\right)^{-1}\left\langle\widetilde{\ell}^{N, \bullet b}, C^{N, \bullet a}-p r_{a}\left(1_{\mathcal{P}_{+}}-1_{\mathcal{P}_{-}}\right)\right\rangle
$$

and point (ii) follows from Cauchy-Schwarz inequality.
Step 3. Proceeding as in Step 2, one can show that
(i) $\widetilde{c}^{N, a b}=(1-\lambda)\left[1_{\mathcal{P}_{a}} \odot A^{N} \widetilde{c}^{N, \bullet b}+\sum_{e \in\{-,+\}}\left(r_{e}^{N}\right)^{-1} \overline{c^{N, e b} C}^{N, a e}+\gamma^{N, a b} 1_{\mathcal{P}_{a}}\right]$,
where
(ii) $\left|\gamma^{N, a b}\right| \leq\left(r_{a}^{N} N\right)^{-1}\left\|L^{N, \bullet a}-\left(a p r_{a}\right) 1_{N}\right\|_{2}\left\|\widetilde{c}^{N, \bullet b}\right\|_{2}$.

Step 4. Here, we prove Equation (87).
From Step 2, one can sum for $a \in\{-,+\}$ to obtain (100)

$$
\widetilde{\ell}^{N, \bullet b}=(1-\lambda)\left[A^{N} \widetilde{\ell}^{N, \bullet b}+\sum_{a \in\{-,+\}} \sum_{e \in\{-,+\}}\left(r_{e}^{N}\right)^{-1} \overline{\ell^{N, e b} L}^{N, a e}+\sum_{a \in\{-,+\}} e^{N, a b} 1_{\mathcal{P}_{a}}\right]
$$

Then, using the fact that $\left\|1_{\mathcal{P}_{x}}\right\|_{2}=N^{1 / 2}\left(r_{a}^{N}\right)^{1 / 2} \leq N^{1 / 2}$, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
&(1-\lambda)^{-1}\left\|\widetilde{\ell}^{N, \bullet b}\right\|_{2} \leq\left\|A^{N}\right\|_{2}\left\|\widetilde{\ell}^{N, \bullet b}\right\|_{2} \\
&+4 \max _{e \in\{-,+\}}\left\{\left(r_{e}^{N}\right)^{-1} \mid \widetilde{\ell}^{N, e b}\right\} \max _{a, e \in\{-,+\}}\left\{\left\|\widetilde{L}^{N, a e}\right\|_{2}\right\}+N^{1 / 2} \sum_{a \in\{-,+\}}\left|e^{N, a b}\right|
\end{aligned}
$$

Recall that $\left\|A^{N}\right\|_{2} \leq 1$ and $\left|\widetilde{\ell}^{N, e b}\right| \leq r_{e}^{N} \lambda^{-1}$ (see inequality (84)). On the event $\mathcal{A}_{N} \supset \mathcal{G}_{N}$, we have $\left\|C^{N, \bullet a}-p r_{a}^{N}\left(1_{\mathcal{P}_{+}}-1_{\mathcal{P}_{-}}\right)\right\|_{2} \leq 2 N^{1 / 4}$, and using Point (ii) of Step 2, we have

$$
\mathbf{1}_{\mathcal{A}_{N}}(1-\lambda)^{-1}\left\|\widetilde{\ell}^{N, \bullet b}\right\|_{2} \leq\left\|\widetilde{\ell}^{N, \bullet b}\right\|_{2}\left[1+\frac{4}{r_{+}^{N} \wedge r_{-}^{N}} N^{-1 / 4}\right]+4 \lambda^{-1} \max _{a, e \in\{-,+\}}\left\{\left\|\widetilde{L}^{N, a e}\right\|_{2}\right\}
$$

Now, since $r_{+}^{N} \wedge r_{-}^{N} \geq r_{\min }$, it follows that $1+\frac{4}{r_{+}^{N} \wedge r_{-}^{N}} N^{-1 / 4} \leq 1+4 r_{\min }^{-1} N^{-1 / 4}<(1-\lambda)^{-1}$ for $N \geq N_{1}$ for some $N_{1}$ sufficiently large. As a consequence, there exists a constant $K$ such that

$$
\mathbf{1}_{\mathcal{A}_{N}}\left\|\widetilde{\ell}^{N, \bullet b}\right\|_{2} \leq K \max _{a, e \in\{-,+\}}\left\{\left\|\widetilde{L}^{N, a e}\right\|_{2}\right\}
$$

and Equations (81) and (82) of Lemma F. 1 implies that

$$
I E\left[\mathbf{1}_{\mathcal{A}_{N}}\left\|\widetilde{\ell}^{N, \bullet b}\right\|_{2}^{4}\right] \leq K I E\left[\max _{a, b \in\{-,+\}}\left\{\left\|\widetilde{L}^{N, a b}\right\|_{2}^{4}\right\}\right] \leq K
$$

for all $N \geq N_{1}$. Taking the maximum value of $I E\left[\mathbf{1}_{\mathcal{A}_{N}}\left\|\tilde{\ell}^{N, \bullet b}\right\|_{2}^{4}\right]$ over all $N \in\left[N_{0}, N_{1}\right]$, we get

$$
I E\left[\mathbf{1}_{\mathcal{A}_{N}}\left\|\widetilde{\ell}^{N, \bullet b}\right\|_{2}^{4}\right] \leq K
$$

for all $N \geq N_{0}$. Yet, inequality 84 implies that $\left|\widetilde{\ell}_{i}^{N, a b}\right| \leq 2 \lambda^{-1}$ which in turn implies that $\left\|\widetilde{\ell}^{N, \bullet b}\right\|_{2}^{4} \leq 4 \lambda^{-2} N^{2}$. Hence, to get rid of the term $\mathbf{1}_{\mathcal{A}_{N}}$ it suffices to write

$$
I E\left[\left\|\widetilde{\ell}^{N, \bullet b}\right\|_{2}^{4}\right] \leq 4 \lambda^{-2} N^{2} I P\left(\left(\mathcal{A}_{N}\right)^{c}\right)+I E\left[\mathbf{1}_{\mathcal{A}_{N}}\left\|\widetilde{\ell}^{N, \bullet b}\right\|_{2}^{4}\right] \leq K
$$

where we used the last inequality of Step 1 with $\alpha=8$.
Finally, the proof of the inequality $I E\left[\left\|\widetilde{c}^{N, \bullet b}\right\|_{2}^{4}\right] \leq K$ follows the same line and is therefore omitted.

Step 5. Here, we prove Equation (85).
We have already used in Step 2 that $\ell^{N, a b}=1_{\mathcal{P}_{a}} \odot\left(1_{\mathcal{P}_{b}}+(1-\lambda) A^{N} \ell^{N, \bullet b}\right)$ Hence, we deduce that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\widetilde{\ell}^{N, a b} & =r_{a}^{N} \delta_{a b}+(1-\lambda) N^{-1} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{P}_{a}} \sum_{j=1}^{N} A^{N}(i, j) \ell_{j}^{N, \bullet b} \\
& =r_{a}^{N} \delta_{a b}+(1-\lambda) N^{-1} \sum_{j=1}^{N} C_{j}^{N, \bullet a} \ell_{j}^{N, \bullet b} \\
& =r_{a}^{N} \delta_{a b}+(1-\lambda) p r_{a}^{N}\left(\widetilde{\ell}^{N,+b}-\widetilde{\ell}^{N,-b}\right)+\eta^{N, a b}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\eta^{N, a b}=(1-\lambda) N^{-1}\left\langle C^{N, \bullet a}-p r_{a}^{N}\left(1_{\mathcal{P}_{+}}-1_{\mathcal{P}_{-}}\right), \ell^{N, \bullet b}\right\rangle$. In particular, we have

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\widetilde{\ell}^{N,+b}-\widetilde{\ell}^{N,-b}=\frac{\left(b r_{a}^{N}\right)}{1-(1-\lambda) p\left(r_{a}^{N}-r_{-}^{N}\right)}+\eta^{N,+b}-\eta^{N,-b} \\
\widetilde{\ell}^{N,+b}+\widetilde{\ell}^{N,-b}=\frac{r_{a}^{N}+2 b(1-\lambda) p r_{a}^{N} r_{-}^{N}}{1-(1-\lambda) p\left(r_{a}^{N}-r_{-}^{N}\right)}+(1-\lambda) p\left(\eta^{N,+b}-\eta^{N,-b}\right)+\eta^{N,+b}+\eta^{N,-b}
\end{array}\right.
$$

and so

$$
\overline{\ell^{N, a b}}=\frac{r_{a}^{N} \delta_{a b}+b(1-\lambda) p r_{+}^{N} r_{-}^{N}}{1-(1-\lambda) p\left(r_{+}^{N}-r_{-}^{N}\right)}+\frac{(1-\lambda) p}{2}\left(\eta^{N,+b}-\eta^{N,-b}\right)+\eta^{N, a b}
$$

Since by our assumption, $\left|r_{+}^{N}-r_{+}\right|+\left|r_{-}^{N}-r_{-}\right| \leq K N^{-1}$, we have
$\left|\frac{r_{a}^{N} \delta_{a b}+b(1-\lambda) p r_{+}^{N} r_{-}^{N}}{1-(1-\lambda) p\left(r_{+}^{N}-r_{-}^{N}\right)}-\frac{r_{a} \delta_{a b}+b(1-\lambda) p r_{+} r_{-}}{1-(1-\lambda) p\left(r_{+}-r_{-}\right)}\right| \leq K\left(\left|r_{+}^{N}-r_{+}\right|+\left|r_{-}^{N}-r_{-}\right|\right) \leq K N^{-1}$,
for some constant $K$ that may depend on $\lambda$, and the result will follow once we check that $\operatorname{IE}\left[\left(\eta^{N, a b}\right)^{2}\right] \leq K N^{-2}$.

To this end, we write $\eta^{N, a b}=(1-\lambda) N^{-1}\left(\eta_{+}^{N, a b}+\eta_{-}^{N, a b}\right)$ where, for $e \in\{-,+\}$, $\eta_{e}^{N, a b}=\left\langle C^{N, e a}-(e p) r_{a}^{N} 1_{\mathcal{P}_{e}}, \ell^{N, e b}\right\rangle$. Remind that $\ell^{N, e b}=\overline{\ell^{N, e b}}+\left(r_{e}^{N}\right)^{-1} \overline{\ell^{N, e b}} 1_{\mathcal{P}_{e}}$. Then, Lemma H. 1 can be applied with $V^{N}=C^{N, e a}-(e p) r_{a}^{N} 1_{\mathcal{P}_{e}}, v_{1}^{N}=0, v_{2}^{N}=\overline{\ell^{N, e b}}$ and $v_{3}^{N}=\left(r_{e}^{N}\right)^{-1} \overline{\ell^{N, e b}} 1_{\mathcal{P}_{e}}$ : assumption (i) is satisfied thanks to Equation (82) and the fact that $\left\|C^{N, e a}\right\|_{\infty} \leq 1$, assumption (ii) is satisfied thanks to Equation (87), assumption (iii) is satisfied thanks to Equations (84) and (80) because $\left\langle V^{N}, v_{3}^{N}\right\rangle=\left(r_{e}^{N}\right)^{-1} \overline{\ell^{N, e b}} \overline{V^{N}}$.

Hence, $\operatorname{IE}\left[\left(\eta_{e}^{N, a b}\right)^{2}\right] \leq K$ which in turn implies that $\operatorname{IE}\left[\left(\eta^{N, a b}\right)^{2}\right] \leq K N^{-2}$.
Step 6. Here we prove Equation (86).
Starting from

$$
c^{N}=\left(Q^{N}\right)^{\top} 1_{N}=\left(I_{N}-(1-\lambda)\left(A^{N}\right)^{\top}\right)^{-1} 1_{N}
$$

we deduce that $c^{N,+\bullet}+c^{N,-\bullet}=c^{N}=1_{N}+(1-\lambda)\left(A^{N}\right)^{\top} c^{N}$, so that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\overline{c^{N, a \bullet}} & =r_{a}^{N}+(1-\lambda) N^{-1} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{P}_{a}} \sum_{j=1}^{N} A^{N}(j, i) c_{j}^{N} \\
& =r_{a}^{N}+(1-\lambda) N^{-1} \sum_{j=1}^{N} L_{j}^{N, \bullet a} c_{j}^{N} \\
& =r_{a}^{N}+(1-\lambda)\left(a p r_{a}^{N}\right) \overline{c^{N}}+\xi^{N, a}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\xi^{N, a}=(1-\lambda) N^{-1}\left\langle L^{N, \bullet a}-\left(a p r_{a}^{N}\right) 1_{N}, c^{N}\right\rangle$. Since $\overline{c^{N}}=\overline{\ell^{N}}$, to conclude the proof of this step it suffices to use Equation (85) and to show that $\operatorname{IE}\left[\left(\xi^{N, a}\right)^{2}\right] \leq K N^{-2}$.

Proceeding as before, we can write $\xi^{N, a}=(1-\lambda) N^{-1}\left(\xi_{+}^{N, a}+\xi_{-}^{N, a}\right)$ where, for $e \in$ $\{-,+\}, \xi_{e}^{N, a}=\left\langle L^{N, e a}-(a p) r_{a}^{N} 1_{\mathcal{P}_{e}}, c^{N, e \bullet}\right\rangle$. Remind that $c^{N, e b}=\widetilde{c}^{N, e b}+\left(r_{e}^{N}\right)^{-1} \overline{c^{N, e b}} 1_{\mathcal{P}_{e}}$. Then, Lemma H. 1 can be applied with $V^{N}=L^{N, e a}-(a p) r_{a}^{N} 1_{\mathcal{P}_{e}}, v_{1}^{N}=0, v_{2}^{N}=\widetilde{c}^{N, e \bullet}$ and $v_{3}^{N}=\left(r_{e}^{N}\right)^{-1} \overline{c^{N, e \bullet}} 1_{\mathcal{P}_{e}}$ : assumption (i) is satisfied thanks to Equation (82) and the fact that $\left\|L^{N, e a}\right\|_{\infty} \leq 1$, assumption (ii) is satisfied thanks to Equation (87), assumption (iii) is satisfied thanks to Equations (84) and (80) because $\left\langle V^{N}, v_{3}^{N}\right\rangle=\left(r_{e}^{N}\right)^{-1} \overline{c^{N, e \bullet} V^{N}}$.

Hence, $\operatorname{IE}\left[\left(\xi_{e}^{N, a}\right)^{2}\right] \leq K$ which in turn implies that $\operatorname{IE}\left[\left(\xi^{N, a}\right)^{2}\right] \leq K N^{-2}$.
Step 7. Here, we prove that $\operatorname{IE}\left[B^{N, \bullet b}\right] \leq K N^{-1 / 2}$ where

$$
B^{N, \bullet b}=\left\|\overline{\ell^{N, \bullet b}}\right\|_{2}^{2}-\left\|(1-\lambda) \sum_{a \in\{-,+\}}\left(r_{a}^{N}\right)^{-1} \overline{\ell^{N, a b}} \bar{L}^{N, \bullet a}\right\|_{2}^{2} \mid
$$

Denoting $y^{N, \bullet b}=\widetilde{\ell}^{N, \bullet b}-(1-\lambda) \sum_{a \in\{-,+\}}\left(r_{a}^{N}\right)^{-1} \overline{\ell^{N, a b}} \widetilde{L}^{N, \bullet a}$, one can use Equation (100) to get
$y^{N, \bullet b}=(1-\lambda)\left[A^{N} y^{N, \bullet b}+(1-\lambda) \sum_{a \in\{-,+\}}\left(r_{a}^{N}\right)^{-1} \overline{\ell^{N, a b}}\left(A^{N} \widetilde{L}^{N, \bullet a}\right)+\sum_{a \in\{-,+\}} e^{N, a b} 1_{\mathcal{P}_{+}}\right]$.
Using the same kind of arguments as in the beginning of Step 4 (except the use of the event $\mathcal{A}_{N}$ ), we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
&((1-\lambda)^{-1}-1)\left\|y^{N, \bullet b}\right\|_{2} \leq 4(1-\lambda) \lambda^{-1} \max _{a, e \in\{-,+\}}\left\{\left\|A^{N} \widetilde{L}^{N, a e}\right\|_{2}\right\} \\
&+\frac{2}{r_{+}^{N} \wedge r_{-}^{N}} N^{-1 / 2}\left\|\widetilde{\ell}^{N, \bullet b}\right\|_{2} \max _{a \in\{-,+\}}\left\|C^{N, \bullet a}-p r_{a}\left(1_{\mathcal{P}_{+}}-1_{\mathcal{P}_{-}}\right)\right\|_{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

Furthermore, using Cauchy-Schwarz inequality, Step 4 of the current Lemma and Equation (82) of Lemma F.1, we have

$$
I E\left[\left\|\widetilde{\ell}^{N, \bullet b}\right\|_{2}^{2} \max _{a \in\{-,+\}}\left\|C^{N, \bullet a}-p r_{a}\left(1_{\mathcal{P}_{+}}-1_{\mathcal{P}_{-}}\right)\right\|_{2}^{2}\right] \leq K
$$

Combining the two equations above by convexity of the square function and then Equation (79) of Lemma F.1, we prove that $y^{N, \bullet b}$ is negligible in the sense that

$$
I E\left[\left\|y^{N, \bullet b}\right\|_{2}^{2}\right] \leq K\left\{I E\left[\max _{a, e \in\{-,+\}}\left\{\left\|A^{N} \widetilde{L}^{N, a e}\right\|_{2}^{2}\right\}\right]+N^{-1}\right\} \leq \frac{K}{N}\right.
$$

In turn, we can prove that $B^{N, \bullet b}$ is negligible. More precisely, we factorize

$$
\begin{aligned}
B^{N, \bullet b}= & \left\|\widetilde{\ell}^{N, \bullet b}\right\|_{2}-\left\|(1-\lambda) \sum_{a \in\{-,+\}}\left(r_{a}^{N}\right)^{-1} \overline{\ell^{N, a b}} \widetilde{L}^{N, \bullet a}\right\|_{2} \mid \\
& \times\left(\left\|\widetilde{\ell}^{N, \bullet b}\right\|_{2}+\left\|(1-\lambda) \sum_{a \in\{-,+\}}\left(r_{a}^{N}\right)^{-1} \overline{\ell^{N, a b}} \widetilde{L}^{N, \bullet a}\right\|_{2}\right) \\
\leq & \left\|y^{N, \bullet b}\right\|_{2}\left(\left\|\widetilde{\ell}^{N, \bullet b}\right\|_{2}+K \max _{a \in\{-,+\}}\left\|\widetilde{L}^{N, \bullet a}\right\|_{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

so that, by Cauchy-Schwarz inequality, and then using Step 4 of the current Lemma and Equations (81) and (82) of Lemma F.1, we get

$$
I E\left[B^{N, \bullet b}\right] \leq K \sqrt{I E\left[\left\|y^{N, \bullet b}\right\|_{2}^{2}\right]} \sqrt{I E\left[\left\|\widetilde{\ell}^{N, \bullet b}\right\|_{2}^{2}+\max _{a \in\{-,+\}}\left\|\widetilde{L}^{N, \bullet a}\right\|_{2}^{2}\right]} \leq \frac{K}{\sqrt{N}}
$$

Step 8. Using the same arguments as Step 7, one can prove that

$$
I E\left[\left\|\widetilde{\ell}^{N}\right\|_{2}^{2}-\left\|(1-\lambda) \sum_{a \in\{-,+\}}\left(r_{a}^{N}\right)^{-1} \overline{\ell^{N, a \bullet}} \widetilde{L}^{N, \bullet a}\right\|_{2}^{2}\right] \leq \frac{K}{\sqrt{N}}
$$

Step 9. Here we prove, for all $a_{1}, a_{2}, b \in\{-,+\}$, that

$$
I E\left[\left|\frac{\widetilde{\ell}^{N, a_{1} b}}{r_{a_{1}}^{N}} \frac{\widetilde{\ell}^{N, a_{2} b}}{r_{a_{2}}^{N}}\left\langle\widetilde{L}^{N, \bullet a_{1}}, \widetilde{L}^{N, \bullet a_{2}}\right\rangle-\delta_{a_{1} a_{2}} \frac{\widetilde{\ell}^{\infty, a_{1} b}}{r_{a_{1}}} \frac{\widetilde{\ell}^{\infty, a_{2} b}}{r_{a_{2}}} r_{a_{1}} p(1-p)\right]\right] \leq \frac{K}{\sqrt{N}}
$$

where $\overline{\ell^{\infty, a b}}:=\frac{r_{a} \delta_{a b}+b(1-\lambda) p r_{+} r_{-}}{1-(1-\lambda) p\left(r_{+}-r_{-}\right)}$is the limit appearing in Equation (85).
Since the coordinates of $\ell^{N, a b}$ are bounded by inequality (84), we know that there exists a constant $K$ such that

$$
\left|\frac{\overline{\ell^{N, a_{1} b}}}{r_{a_{1}}^{N}} \frac{\overline{\ell^{N, a_{2} b}}}{r_{a_{2}}^{N}}-\frac{\overline{\ell^{\infty, a_{1} b}}}{r_{a_{1}}} \frac{\overline{\ell^{\infty, a_{2} b}}}{r_{a_{2}}}\right| \leq K\left(\left|\frac{\overline{\ell^{N, a_{1} b}}}{r_{a_{1}}^{N}}-\frac{\overline{\ell^{\infty, a_{1} b}}}{r_{a_{1}}}\right|+\left|\frac{\overline{\ell^{N, a_{2} b}}}{r_{a_{2}}^{N}}-\frac{\overline{\ell^{\infty, a_{2} b}}}{r_{a_{2}}}\right|\right)
$$

Hence, using Equation (85), Cauchy-Schwarz inequality twice and finally Equations (81) and (82) of Lemma F.1, we have

$$
